reviewText:
As someone who has over 200+ hours in OMD2, I really love this franchise.  With that being said, OMDU being FTP really concerned me.  Most FTP is poorly implemented and done in a way that punishes the player if they don't dish out several games worth of money into them to make progress.  And based on what I was hearing, it sounded like OMDU was going down that exact path.

Unfortunately, it looks like it really was.

OMDU plays better than ever.  The gameplay is great, the new roster of characters is a nice change of pace, and the new abilities and traps are a welcomed addition.  I am already addicted to the gameplay and would love to keep playing.  But, the problem is, is that most players will never experience 1/3rd of what this game has to offer due to the INCREDIBLE cost of literally everything in this game.  Want a new trap?  Better hope you have either a padded wallet or 30 hours of grinding on your hand.  A new character?  Well that costs even more, better pick which arm and leg you want to give up.  The costs are absolutely astronomical and brutally punishing.

Which is incredibly disappointing actually, because all of the charm from OMD was leveling up, getting new traps, getting new gear, getting new weapons, upgrading it all and trying to find that PERFECT setup for each specific level.  But with OMDU, it's just This is what you have
date: grind match after match after match and MAYBE
recommended: JUST MAYBE after a couple days you can get the base variant for a single new trap if you're lucky."\n\nIt's such a flipping shame
hoursPlayed: because I would've gladly paid full price for this game and enjoyed the living heck out of it had they not gone the FTP route.  But now
voteText: I am honestly questioning whether or not I will continue on with this game knowing that I either have to shovel truckloads of money into it to make any progress or grind for weeks and weeks and weeks just to get a decent variety of traps and characters.\n\nHopefully Robot will decrease the insane cost to make progress in this game.  If not
helpfulPercent: they're likely to lose a longtime dedicated fan."

reviewText:
I normally don't write reviews, but I've been seeing a LOT of unfair reviews for this game, so here goes.

Many people have written bad reviews based solely on the partnership with Gameforge as a publisher. I agree, it was a poor choice, but giving a great game a bad review because of the publisher is ridiculous.

Also, many people have complained that this game is a MOBA. That's also ridiculous, because that is ONE game mode. Survival is the classic tower defense that we all know and love from OMD and OMD2, except that we have the option of playing it with a larger party if we wish (the level will scale in difficulty based on party size). Also, the MOBA-ish game mode that is Siege just happens to feel like a natural next step for the game. Hmm

reviewText:
This game has real potential, however in it's current form I do not recommend it. The developers of this sequel seem to have missed what so many people loved about the first two games - the ability to purchase and upgrade items in order to take on more challenging maps. The item system for OMD and OMD2 was simple, and relatively quick. Not so in this ill conceived chapter of the OMD franchise.

After 81 hours I've managed to upgrade two traps to level 2 (of 4 possible levels), and buy 1 hero. The upgrade system is overly complex, and the materials cost of purchasing upgrades is simply absurd. In order to upgrade five traps to level 4 you would be looking at literaly thousands of hours of farming.

Sorry Robot Entertainment, I'm not looking to spend 3,000 or 5,000 hours grinding survival matches to upgrade my traps. No one is - hence the currently 'mixed' review score on Steam, and even worse scores elsewhere.

reviewText:
It's not a Pay to Win.
Here's what's changed from OMD2: in addition to killing orcs with traps, two new strategic changes have been made. The combo system is now much more important to success, and can't spam tar and arrow walls to win like before; you'll be broke and ogres will be trampling over your tiny baby-man corpse. You will have to vary the traps you use and keep in mind the damage properties of the traps (and sometimes even heroes) to maximize funds. The second major change is that rerouting orcs to where you want them to be (and where they really, really don't want to be) is key to success. Barriers will become your friend, and sappers will make you cry tears of blood.
Here's why it's not Pay to Win.

List of Things That Cannot be Purchased With Real-World Money:
- Traps
- Trinkets (called gear in this game, same thing)
- Guardians (some can be obtained if you buy the packs for the game, but otherwise not for sale)
- Traits (passive bonuses to your character)
- Minions (PVP)
- Bosses (PVP)
- Materials

List of Things That Can ONLY be Purchased with Money:
- Skins

Consumables and characters can be bought, but they can also be crafted. However, it is important to note that the materials needed for crafting characters are not found in low level maps and it will take you a while to reach the point where high level enemies spawn to find those drops.
And that's where I think all of the negative press comes from. Almost all of the negative reviews come from people with 4 hours or less of gameplay, so they don't really understand how this game works, they just played it, saw it wasn't OMD2, and downvoted it and started crying about it.
It is not P2W, it's very well made, if you like OMD2, you will like this, as long as you have the patience to level up a lot before being able to hit the big leagues with fancier upgraded traps and consumables.

reviewText:
I reget to say it, but Im fairly disapointed with the direction they took the franchise with this one. OMD 1&2 were simple and beautiful and nailed what they were tring to do. I cant help but feel like someone got greedy with the decision to make it into a PVP MOBA game, and now OMD:U doesnt seem like it knows what it wants to be. There is crafting, grinding, TD, battle arena. The neat and clean UI has been replaced by loads of cluttered and confusing menues. Lots of pickups, none of them feel meanigful or intuative...

Its not all bad. Theres some good stuff here, but its a far cry from what would make me continue throwing money at the franchise. The same level of humor is still there, and the art style is on point. The PVE/Co-op aspects are great, alot of which would undoubtedly qualify for OMD sucessor status if it were not for the stunted grindy crafting system encouraging you to buy booster packs to increase drops and experience.

I would have happily bought OMD3 outright for a heafty sum, but nothing turns me off of a game faster than a micro-transaction reliant buisness model.

reviewText:
To call this a grind would be unfair to actual grinds.  They will bait you in by feeding you enough crafting materials as leveling rewards to craft a hero and a couple of traps, but all the interesting traps are gated behind materials with drop rates so low that they might as well not be in the loot table.  You know it's bad when a studio employee publicly admits to using an exploit to farm materials.

There's also what I would call a steep strategy and teamwork curve for survival matches.  Matchmaking and map difficulty are determined by account level and it's very easy to find yourself on maps that require a cohesive strategy executed as a team within just a few hours. Because every hero level advances your account level, it almost feels like a punishment for trying different heroes once you find yourself consistently losing on the advanced maps.

While I don't think it's fair to call the game pay-to-win, I would call it pay-to-enjoy.  You NEED upgraded traps to make a difference as the difficulty ramps up, but with the aforementioned dearth of materials needed to craft and upgrade them then the only other option to acquire them becomes purchasing chests with cash.  The drops from the chests are randomized, so if you go this route be prepared to burn through some money.

With the initial flush of materials you get in the first levels, it's also very easy to make the mistake of thinking this represents the progression you'll see in later levels and make sub-optimal upgrade and crafting decisions.  By the time you actually have a feel for the game and what traps work well together, you're in a materials desert and stuck with the choices you made when you didn't know what you were doing.

The carrot on the stick in this game is the traps, but when you find yourself playing game after game with the same starter traps and the few traps you were able to craft with the early level rewards, the drop rate on the materials needed to craft new traps really starts to become demotivating.

There's potential for a really fun game here and I really want to enjoy it, but right now it's all stick and no carrot.

reviewText:
TL;DR Great gameplay, very enjoyable and challenging, addictive. It's a F2P multiplayer game, not P2W, Different from OMD1 and 2. It has PvE and PvP, not grindy at all for a F2P. Regular updates, the devs listen to people, fast fixes.

Most negative reviews talk about things that have been adressed like the slow progression/p2w feeling and will keep being adressed actively with patches.

This game has good graphics, and it's really well done taking into account that is F2P and not from a huge studio.
The gameplay is very enjoyable and addictive.
It's not casual and super easy like OMD1 and 2 was, it shifted into a bit more competitive and challenging stuff like the PvP. Early levels of PvE are still plain easy.
The PvE progression is slower than OMD1/2 but that makes the game not that boring too, it has a longer campaign, more heroes to play and you can still choose to play solo or up to 5 people (the game autobalances the level for you).

Also new traps, gear, minions, bosses, etc.

The PvP mode is still a tower defense but inspired by MOBA" aspects from games like HoTS. It's quite fast-paced and really engaging

reviewText:
I played the Closed Beta for 19 months and have been through a lot of ups and downs with this game.

The PvP is currently really enjoyable, it’s fast paced and full of action. Every role and hero is entertaining in their own way. The focus for the Closed Beta was to get the core game play polished, this has left us with a bit less content than you might want from a game like this, it could use a few more different Minions and Heroes.

PvE is still lacking a bit, allthough since its introduction to OMDU a year ago it has grown at an almost insane pace, so I have no doubt that it will become amazing at one point. If you’re not happy with it now, put the game away for a while and come back later, if development in Open Beta will follow the same pattern as in Closed you won’t be dissapointed when you come back.

The businessmodel and crafting system does look a bit messy at first glance. Some of it, not all, is due to an unpolished UI for crafting making it seem more grindy that it actually is. Free players will be able to enjoy this game a lot, even though it feels a bit slow to get off the ground.

reviewText:
So here's the skinny: This game is pretty good, but not perfect yet... though, remember it's only on open beta phase, so it's to be expected, and patches are coming in regularly, so it looks good so far.

Let's get on with the obvious first: Yes, it's a free to play. Yes, it's VERY grindy (as you can expect from any F2P game).

That said: NO, it's NOT pay to win. Not at all in fact, since money will get you characters, skins, consumables (a bit useless tbh and PvE only) and chests. Now, chests are luck based basically, and you will get PLENTY of chests for free while playing anyways, so paying would in fact just give you more random ressources than non-paying players, but it's still luck based, so it doesn't really make that much of  a difference in the end.

You'll start with enough items to be able to play right away and not feel under-powered, and the reality is: this is a lot more skill-based (and strategy-based) than item-based.

Okay, so, with that said... 2nd thing: This is NOT a MOBA game... Yes, the Siege mode" has MOBA mechanics

reviewText:
OMDU is a fantastic adaption of 3rd person multiplayer tower defense. It builds upon OMD 1 and 2 in ways that fans of those games would enjoy while being also a unique multiplayer experience with both its co-op and competitive modes. I have been playing it off and on since it's closed alpha and find the current Open Beta to be absolutely wonderful if still a bit rough around the edges.

Allow me to clear up some common misconceptions about this game.
-Is this just another 3rd person atempt at a MOBA?
No. Its  Siege mode (competitive mode) does have a lot in common with MOBAs, but it is reductive and incorrect to classify it as just another MOBA." It's not a 3rd person version of DOTA or League. If you come to OMDU expecting that you'll be disappointed. While I would certainly classify the Siege mode as "MOBA-like" it has it's own unique spin on the concepts and requires its own skill set.
Example: Each team has offensive and defensive lanes. When on defense you'll be setting traps and arranging the path that the enemy minions will take just like you would in the other OMD games. While on offense you'll be trying to push back or defeat those defenders to get your minions through.

-Is this game only multiplayer?
Sort of. There is a Survival Mode (co-op) that can be played single player
date: but you'll likely find that it quickly becomes really difficult. At the moment the Survival mode appears to only have varients of the Siege mode maps
recommended:
but it would not surprise me if they make Survival only maps or even port some of the classic maps from the other games to that mode. It should be mentioned that Survival has it's own mechanics that do not appear in the Siege mode such as placable Guardians and an "Unchained" meter (which is sort of similar to Marvel Vs Capcom 3's X-Factor in that it give the character a powerful buff for a short peroid.)

Who would I recommend this game to?
If you're looking for a unique multiplayer game and enjoy either tower defense or the previous installments then you should at least check this game out. It still has some ironing out but any grievences I have with the game are too specific to bring up in a review (like certain character having more costumes than others
hoursPlayed: or fiddly balance stuff.)\nIt is free to play but the current progression seems pretty fair. You seem to get a pretty steady stream of new things from just playing the game."

reviewText: Even a casual glance at human history will tell you that greed is easily the foremost destroyer of good things, big and small.  This (small) game is just its latest victim.  Don't go blaming the devs though.  As an artist working in the game industry since the early 2000s I can pretty much guarantee you that this wasn't their choice.  It's always the owners who pull this crap.  The devs are just like you. We understand the negative force that  freemium represents with regards to gaming and we loath it both as creators and as players.  Don't worry though- even if some people choose to support this garbage there will always be others who don't, and the games for them will be the games for you.  Unless of course you like being taken advantage of by sleazy payment structures designed to rob you blind while offering you little. In which case, enjoy Orcs Must Die Unchained! Also: Go to hell :D

reviewText:
Even though I enjoy the game, i would not recommend playing this.

Positive:
-The pace, everything just feels faster and more fluent. Really adds up to the tension.
-Difficulty for now, is right on spot. I lose some, win most (but not with 100% rift). Which is great!
-Different heroes, leveling, play style. Minor downside is that you can't choose more skill upgrades after level 12?
-Lots of traps and high trap placement cap.
-Awesome Guardians.
-Hero variation + you get 5 of them f2p for one week.
-Fun siege mode which can be ignored if you don't like it.

Negative:
-Most people will be bored before they unlock even 1/10th of the game. Rather 1/20 of the game. I'm still not there.
-Lots of traps, you'll never get to enjoy because of the insane cost.
-No point in trying and testing the traps you love the most => insane cost, so you'll never have even 1/4th of the traps
-Upgrading traps is even more of a joke, even higher cost
-Hero cost is also insane
-Drop rate is horrible compared to crafting cost
-No variation at all when you play with other players => nobody can get any new traps because of the insane cost
-You can't place archers/fighters anymore. Why remove this awesome feature?

Conclusion:
This is still a beta, so things may change. They reduced the hero cost from overpriced, to less overpriced. I want to enjoy this game with other players, seeing all kinds of trap variations and fun combinations. Sadly, 80% of the player base will probably quit before reaching any new traps, due to this insane cost.

You are PUNISHED for trying different kinds of traps. There is absolutely NO WAY you'll get around testing and upgrading various traps, due to high cost, weeks and weeks of grinding to just upgrade even 1 trap. I don't mind who the developer is, but I can't believe they would enjoy their own game for a long time because of the lack of variation, only due to high costs. Orcs will prevail like this.

This review can easily be turned into positive... Listen to your fans. We'll pay for a good and fair priced game. Not for this. I don't mind a grind, but this is ridiculous.

reviewText:
Bought the game way back when the game was originally announced, and I'm finding that I just dont enjoy the game compared to OMD and OMD2.

Because the team decided to make it a 'free to play' game a lot of the systems that I enjoyed playing with in the originals have been replaced by a un-rewarding grindfest. Even though they're supposedly fixing the drop system, you can't experiment with different builds or traps to see what you like; and even if you have the resources a LOT of the good traps/equipment/etc is random drop from chests only.

I can see a lot of potential in the core mechanics, it's just buried so far underneath the systems designed to 'encourage' players to invest money in the market that it just ruins the game for me.

I bought the founders pack way back, way back when the game was announced and I completely regret it now. The founder's deal gave a bunch of unique skins and offered more gold than the current packs for a lower price. Even with the better deal the game isn't worth it, wish I could get a refund based on the current game.

The way the game is now, I doubt the system will ever be rewarding enough to casual players or people that don't want to invest the money.

reviewText:
A lot of people may still be basing their thoughts no the game on the perceived notion that the game is still nothing but a MOBA, but they couldn't be further from the truth.

With changes during closed beta, they added Survival which feels more in line to the classic OMD1/2 feel. Traps can be a little grindy to grind for the materials, and craft, but it honestly isn't too bad if you're going to be playing it regularly.

Plus, you can bring 4 other friends with you to slay hordes of orcs, instead of just one like before.

I like it, I say give it a try!

Edit: Just wanted to touch on Siege (the moba mode) - It has a pretty high skill cap, and it can be pretty difficult to figure out everything that may be going on, but if that's the kind of game you like, I encourage giving it a try.

Anyone that calls this pay to win can eat a major one, because you can craft anything in game barring skins with in game materials. And buying chests does not guarantee you the materials to advance as quick as you might think. Trust me, my gold I bought from closed beta were spent strictly on heroes, and the chests I purchased with leftover, didn't yield much in the way of useful items. It is definitely not pay to win, and in fact, I'd suggest against buying gold and getting chests too much.

Does the game have its faults? Well yeah, what doesn't?  The game holds my attention because it's survival mode is similar to OMD 2, and it allows me to group with up to 4 others, and there are more heroes and IMO, the gameplay feels pretty gratifying.

Again, this is my opinion, and I would recommend anyone to give it a try. What do you have to lose? It is free after all.

reviewText:
I really wish they could of just left this game the way it was... I was such a HUGE fan of 1 and 2 there was really nothing like it, the humor, gameplay, silly story, single player/co-op frenzy

Isn't the saying if it's not broken don't fix it"

It would of been fine to create this game on the side but after this long of a wait (which now I understand why because they did pretty much a total re-vamp of the game) but we could of at least had a Orcs Must Die 3 along to go with it for it's original fan owners of the game

It's hard to say... Is it a bad game? NO is this still the same game it was before? NO

Long story short if you loved the older orcs must die for it's casual sit down single player/co-op with another friend campaign fun beat it in a few days... This is 100% a whole new game that'll take hours of grinding to unlock all your traps/abilities/skins/chracters/etc it essentially is playing another MOBA type forumla game... Sure it has a nice twist to it but to really make most of this game... be prepared to play this for the long run and long nights to really get most out of it

I'm saddened but happpy for the game it is trying to reach new heights but honestly it was a perfect game the way it was... Why couldn't we just get the same game with the new heroes and new challenging locations for the extended replayability

The MOBA scene is already dominated already by the 2 kings trying to go up against them or stand with them or re-invent the formula is just foolish should of just stuck to creating the same great game... Change isn't always a good thing"

reviewText:
This game hurts me as a long follower of the OMD! games. I played OMD! 1 and 2 through, even the endless maps ontop, so much fun did i had with the games. But this, this is not the sequel i wanted nor needed.

It looks like OMD! but, it feels so wrong, so very, very wrong. And maybe thanks to Gameforge, did i just now learned about OMD! U. And thank god for that.

Pros:
-Interesting Heroes to choose from, once you unlocked them either through grinding or RNG shop with money
-All the traps from the earlier games are there! But not all, you have to unlock them again through grinding or RNG shop
-The levels and survival maps (runs? Missions? Not sure how to call them) are nice and fitting into OMD! But there are only few now, and the few are getting boring quickly.
-Good ol' OMD! humor is inclusive and free!
-Ummm...skins for your heroes? No, wait, you have to unlock them through leveling and RNG shop too.

Cons:
-Almost all the mentioned points up there
-Graphics are looking horrible
-Tutorials are stuttering! No joke, my pc is able to run The Division on ultra smoothly, but the tutorials of this game are stuttering for no reason!
- GRINDING! Everyone playing this game can assure you, that if you want to play free, you have to grind, ALOT.
-Crafting. Yes, the tedious amount of crafting is a con too. You have to craft almost everything in this game.
-MOBA. Sadly yes, the MOBA aspect is a con too. Other players with money can unlock early on Heroes, you don't know and know how to fight. Put in the level imbalance and upraded Traps imbalance, that can happen, and your game is over.
-It feels like you have to put in cash to get somewhere in the game, into a shop to buy chests with RNG. Great.
-As some others mentioned, the Community isn't happy at all about Gameforge and Robot, ignoring and stealing ideas for Patches and more.


Overall, ignore it, or better, play some round first, than get back here and give it a negative Review. This game doesn't have deserved it, to be here on Steam, insulting the OMD! series. Kill this game out of mercy, not out of hate.

reviewText:
What is this game?
Is it a MOBA? Is it a tower defense?
It offers elements from both.  The PvP is my favorite mode, it offers a high skill cap, a difficult learning curve but it is worth it.  Anyone coming from another MOBA will quickly understand how to learn and master heroes, but the new element of escorting minions and defending against them is fresh and an added level of difficulty.
Defense is a losing battle.  You will lose, eventually, but your goal is to outlast the enemy team's defense.  It is the job of the offense to make sure the other team's defense loses faster.
There is a very large skill gap between new and old players.  Don't give up too early.  You have a lot to learn.
If you stick with it, and find some friends to play with and learn with, it will pay off.
Can't wait to see the ESports scene develop around this game.
Regardless, it's free, you have nothing to lose.  Give it a try, you might be as impressed as I was.

reviewText:
The core gameplay of this game is admittedly decent. I, presonally, found no real purchase in the versus aspect of the game. It makes otherwise good gameplay feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ moba that was forced into the game rather than designed into it.

The base coop mode is more of what you have come to expect from orcs must die in the past, and its done well enough. However, it does feel like it is done worse than in previous games. They reworked some mechanics (ex. guardians are stronger but VERY limited, think just a couple per map, and can only be placed in designated spots) and shifted the focus away from the traps a bit and more onto the player's character. Personally, I really dislike this choice. They did add in quite a few characters and an ingame talent choice system similar to Heroes of the Storm, but it ultimately still feels fairly hollow.

The worst part of the game has to be the progression system. There are multiple types of currency that you have to collect from various sources and the drop rate makes it feel like you are making hardly any progress at all. It basically feels like they took what was in the previous games, and took everything away from the character in order to force you to buy it all back in this game.

The absolute worst decision I can think of is also related to this progression system. Account levels are gained as you gain experience for different characters by playing them and levelling them up. The problem with this is that players that are too far apart in levels cannot play with each other in full groups. My friend showed me this game and so I decided to try it. However, because we are too far apart in levels, we can only play together with the two of us and can not get into a matchmaking group. The problem with this is that everything in this game definitely feels like it was designed for a full 5 players. The game does scale back the enemies to compensate, but the map design and everything else just screams at you the entire time that you should have 5 players and that is the way the game is meant to be played. But you can't. the game gives no indication or explanation to what is happening and you have to dig through old patch notes to figure out that they wanted to make it so that the matchmaker wouldn't just average out the players levels and leave moderately leveled people playing with one much higher level and one noob. They give absolutely no indication of when you will be able to play together the way the game feels like it was meant to be played. You just have to keep ranking up hoping this will be the one that does it. Worst system ever. I have no idea why anyone would impliment a system that actively discourages players from playing with their friends.

Its not like the problem I described above is just a newby problem either. there are 100 account levels, and as far as I can tell, a difference of 10 will mean you can't matchmake together. Again, despite my best efforts and a long time looking, there is no information other than one sentence in some patch notes a short while back explaining it.

reviewText:
I've played this game outside of Steam so ignore my play time.

Microtransactions make this game pay-to-win.  Don't bother with it.

It's pay-to-win because of consumables and weapons which you can buy with real money that give you an advantage over those who don't purchase them.  Also, the ridiculous amount of grinding you need to do to unlock characters and craft things.  The devs deliberately made the pay wall the more attractive choice in comparison to grinding.

Making money on skins is fine.

Making money on keys or crates is fine.

I understand they need to be paid for their work, I never disputed that for a moment.  I think that the F2P model they choose to use is garbage.

Get the original Orcs Must Die and Orcs Must Die 2 instead.

reviewText:
I was an early backer for this game because I absolutely loved OMD and OMD2. The developers are really nice people and from their other efforts they're generally good at their jobs. I really wanted to like this. It's just... not good.

It's trying to be a MOBA in a space where we just don't need MOBAs. I have DotA 2. I don't need another one.

Yes, there is now a PvE mode but that doesn't solve the problem because the game was still designed around PvP and suffers as a result. It lost all the shine and fun in the original series.

The physics aren't zany, off-the wall, and sometimes glitchy. Hero characters can't equip multiple weapons to create unique play-styles. Hero attacks are balanced" instead of just letting you be a maniacal orc killing machine. The strategic/puzzle element of the game at the harder difficulty levels is gone. There were some levels on nightmare my friend and I played like 7-8 times before we finally figured out a winning 5-skull strategy and that was really rewarding
date: then we'd check online and other people would have completely different solutions. The cap on total traps per level prevents you from making an insane unstoppable meat grinder and watching it work.\n\nI could go on
hoursPlayed: this game has no soul. It compromised what made it great to force it into an oversaturated genre no one wanted it to be in. I just hope its failure doesn't ruin the developers because I would still like to buy OMD3 one day."

reviewText: I want to give this game a neutral" rating but I have to pick positive or negative and I think the negative is more apt.\n\nI don't have the same complaints as other people - the siege mode doesn't bother me (I got it to play the PvE mode with friends) and I don't care about the micro-transactions
date:
I just feel like it doesn't do OMD2 justice. It feels like a different game.

None of my complaints are things that can't be balanced before the full launch and I'd love to come back and recommend this game as things progress but as it stands right now after playing 4-5 matches with my friends I have issues with the following things:

1) The gate/guardian mechanic is weird. OMD2 was corridors to place traps in and create kill boxes. I find that more often than not in a 4 player game we wind up just wailing on enemies that are wailing on a blue barrier. This stems from my second complaint -

2) There isn't nearly enough room to place traps. Nothing in OMD2 was more satisfying than setting up a bad ♥♥♥ killbox that you got to watch enemies evaporate in for a wave or 2. You don't get that in this game. You have little tiny restricted areas in which to place a few traps and it's not enough to really make much of a dent in the later waves of enemies. The traps feel like an after-thought instead of a core gameplay mechanic like they were in previous games.

3) Along with there not being enough room to place traps the balance of money earned on waves and trap costs is way out of whack. The fun factor of this game would increase 10 fold if we got more coins per wave and were given more space to place traps. The trap power feels pretty okay (frost vents are still trash
hoursPlayed: tar for life) but it just feels like you don't have much room for creativity
voteText:
nor the cash to be creative with trap placement.

3) Hero balance is way out of whack. Melee level up at least 2x as fast as ranged because they can hit every single enemy while the ranged shoot the melee in the back (thankfully no FF) instead of hitting enemies.

4) All hero power is way out of whack. They are all far too weak to be fun to play. Even the most basic enemies take way too many hits to the kill to the point that you don't feel powerful just annoyed that nothing dies in a timely fashion. It would be a lot more fun to be able to kill enemies faster but have more enemies to kill
helpfulPercent: with the exception of the classic exceptions which are supposed to be really tanky and hard to kill. I know the game has the different gear and traits but honestly looking at them none of them look very exciting. 12% more damge to ogres - hold the phones did someone say 12 whole percent? Against a single enemy class? Whoopie. I think the heroes should all be baseline probably 2x as powerful as they are
votesHelpful: the amount of enemies increased to compensate
votesTotal: and the traits changed to more creative/engaging buffs. Faster movement speed after X number of combos in a set time period
votesFunny: chance to set fire or slow or freeze enemies on hit
commentsCount: chance to trigger double damage against certain classes
column16: etc.\n\n5) The special abilities are all really underwhelming. I haven't played every hero but the ones I have tried have all had really underwhelming Q and E abilities
column17:
and the V overcharge type ability is really underwhelming. There are some exceptions - I liked the fire ladies dragon's breath type channeled ability and Hogarths damage reduction is super handy but his leap ability? It's non targetable and practically a death sentence if you leap into the wrong group of enemies. I'd rather something more useful like a frost breath frontal AOE slow or a ground stop type stun. Especially with the lack of trap placement taking away most of the killbox gameplay the characters should have more CC available.

6) The respawn timer is too long when you die. Probably 2x too long. Drop the initial cooldown WAY down and make it increase with each death IMO.

7) Please for the love of everything good and holy give Maximillian the shotgun back. That stupid bow is total trash.

I think it has a lot of potential and people new to OMD might like it but for people who've been salivating for a 4-5 player co-op OMD since OMD2 are going to be disappointed. A great start but could use some tweaks to make it more fun."

reviewText:
Huge OMD1 and 2 fan, bought the game for friends yada yada.

Got in on the closed beta and was quickly disappointed. That was nearly two years ago, figured I'd give the PvE a try since the word is it's like the old OMD".

I'll save you the read: it's not.

Am I just a bitter PC Masterace type guy who doesn't want anything to change ever?  Am I just mad because it went F2P?  Let's look at the facts.

Here's a PARTIAL list of things that were changed.  Most of this has nothing to do with the F2P model
recommended:
but everything to do with what helped make the first two games good:

Here's a partial list of what was made worse:

1. No Single Player campaign* (a tacked on solo experience with no story and no progression)
2. No Double-jumping
3. No Head shots
4. No Sprinting (yes
hoursPlayed: you cannot sprint in this game!)\n5. Slow rate of fire\n6. Bad guys are bullet sponges
voteText:
primary weapons are nearly useless (except to add a hit to your combo counter)
7. No charge shots
8. Traps do less damage and fire less often.
9. Traps cost more and thus you place far fewer in the course of a match. (If you manage to lay down 10 traps in the course of a half hour match
helpfulPercent: that's about typical in this game)\n10. No trinkets\n11. Slow movement: as mentioned
votesHelpful: no sprinting
votesTotal: but backing up or strafing are oddly far slower than moving forward.\n12. Character stops dead to cast magic or melee (again
votesFunny:
adding to the SLOW feeling of this game)
13. The excellent progression of unlocking traps each level in OMD 1 and 2 is replaced with a deliberately complicated crafting system that requires (literally) dozens of hours of grinding to make any real progress.
14. Most levels limit trap placement to a single small hallway. The entire trap mechanic in the game is hugely downplayed.
15. Guardians cannot be placed strategically
commentsCount: only on designated spots\n16. Auto-aim/bullet magnetism has been added (explains why no headshots)"

reviewText:
I want to give this game a thumbs up.  I really do.  The game is fun, the graphics good, the little bits of humour from OMD are there.

But I can't.

In its current setup the game is massively PAY TO WIN.  In a full release this is almost always a game killer.  In the beta?  ♥♥♥♥ that ♥♥♥♥.  This is the BETA.  You want your players trying everything out.  You want them to push the limits of what the game can handle.  Putting artificial barriers in the way, especially barriers that are there for no reason but to pull money in early, is just unforgivable.

To make matters even worse the amounts are ridiculous.  A person could very easily spend hundreds of dollars on the beta, only risk the possibility of having it all wiped out with the advent of new beta versions or the full release.  So, with heavy heart I have to give Orcs Must Die Unchained a thumbs down.  Provisionally.....get rid of the pay to win, at least for the beta and I'll change this review.

reviewText:
Spent 70 hours with the game, bought two hero packs (the cheaper ones). I did enjoy the earlygame but as soon as the grindwall hits you in the face the fun ends. After 70 hours i don't have any tier3 traps thats needed in order to beat lvl70+ maps (im lvl76 myself). So survival is pretty screwed and gets really boring after awhile. I had faith early on aswell that the devs would change and improve the progression-system, but little has been done.

So it all ends with Siege, problem here is that we have the same grindwall. People that bought plenty of chests (with random loot) will have more traits and traps. Feels its a softversion of p2w, and it all goes down in how the devs failed with the progression-system. After 70 hours i have 1x trait and 1x pvptrap.

So overall i guess it's fine since its F2P, but i honestly wish i didn't support this crap. After around 20-30 hours the game starts to feel more like a job.

reviewText:
Played for half a day... got bored...

Graphically, the game looks nice.  Still has a bunch of halarious speech from all the characters.  The dialogue is always well written.  However, this was not enough appeal to keep me interested.

The game is a grind.  You will see the same maps over and over again.  The feel of power and stradegy from the original games is gone from this game.  No longer will you have nice sized kill-boxes.  They decided that you can only build in certain spots on the maps.  Really, the maps have a TON of areas where you just cannot build, or cannot build in any decent way.

Characters in the game feel like they were nerfed, nerfed again, and again.  No more charging weapons up.  No more headshots.  You basically sit there and hold down your attack button.  Even then, you will see hardly any damage against the orc hordes.

Pretty much, the game is slow, a grind, repetitive, and cash shops = UGGGHSSS....... ;(   If this game played like the other two, it may be fun, seeing dead orcs everywhere, seeing orcs burnt to a crisp, melted by acid, thrown off the map into canyons, etc... sadly, this game isn't nearly as fun.

reviewText:
Another example of action rpg (lite) tower defense hybrid genre killing itself.  First it was Dungeon Defenders 2 now Orcs Must Die Unchained.

Why a MOBA?  This game's style is not suited towards a MOBA.  Moreover, the popular MOBA's on the market don't require tedious grinding or microtransactions to unlock all hero skills/abilities.  DOTA2 only has cosmetic microtransactions.  Heroes of the Storm requires you to unlock heroes with gold which is slightly more tedious but passable.  OMD Unchained requires you to unlock heroes AND purchase unlocks/upgrades for traps and items to increase your hero's power.

Co-op Survival mode suffers from the same grinding feeling but the awkwardness of playing with four teammates.  Strategically planning trap placement is not something you want to do with four random players who often don't comunicate at all.  Never mind the fact the load times and 'waiting for player' queues are extremely frustrating versus OMD 1 and 2's drop in and get started right away.

A sad end to a great franchise.  I'd have gladly paid $30 for an OMD 3 that includes much of the same content (new heroes, traps, items, levels, even some grinding) but focused on single player and two to three person co-op modes.

reviewText:
The game itself is pretty good. It's hard to be in the game, and not having fun. When the game is playing and you're in it - it's a good time.

Everything else is kinda trashy. It will take you ages to unlock any character. I've played 12 games and won 6 of them - sure you can use that to say I'm not very good at the game, but this is a game where I have no control over 9 of the 10 players in it - and that has amounted to 17 rift embers. You need 450 rift embers to unlock a character. If I'm averaging about 2 embers per game, this game is asking you to play about 225 games to unlock one character.

Let's suppose you want to be a good digital citizen and purchase characters one by one for real dollars. You like the game and want to support it with money. Okay.

Each character costs some amount of premium currency which can only be purchased with actual money so the fact that these characters aren't just being sold for actual money is already one level of unnecessary obscurity. The premium currency needed to unlock a character CANNOT BE PURCHASED. Premium currency can only be bought in increments of 1,250 (250 per $) - 2,750 (275 per $)- 5,750 (287.5 per $) - 15,000 (300 per $) - and 32,500 (325 per $) while characters themselves range from 900 to 2500.

Unlocking every character in the game would cost 21,700 premium currency.

While the question: what's the best deal? might make for an interesting math problem, this system is virtually guaranteed to overcharge you by making exact change impossible. For someone mathematically inclined it is a puzzle . . . probably the best value is to buy 5$ worth at 2,750 and use that to get the 3 cheap heroes.

This cash shop is asking for at least $60, just for the characters. It's asking at least that again for all the various accoutrements.

I just . . . I don't see the value there. In terms of production value, I don't see 60$ up on the screen. This game is way too expensive to own so the question you should be asking yourself is: what portion of the pie do I think is worth playing? It's a question I hate to ask myself when I'm just trying to enjoy the game.

I get that this developer probably doesn't want you to unlock characters too quickly for perfectly valid reasons. It's free to play, they need to make their money back somehow. There's not that many characters in the game, if you were unlocking them super fast you'd be done way too quickly. That last reason is maybe just padding - but it feels like it has more weight than just nothing.

The game's fun, I'm probably going to keep playing it, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ if unlocking anything isn't extremely arduous.

reviewText:
I'm not really good at writing these types of reviews but I felt the current mixed rating this game has is, in my opinion, undeserving. So I'm hoping that this review might help people look past the current rating.

So what is Orcs Must Die!: Unchained? It's a MOBA combined with turret defense type gameplay (or trap defense in this case). In most MOBAs (say DOTA 2) minions spawn from 3 lanes from a barracks type structure and head towards a main structure in the enemy's base to attack and destroy between them are Heros (players) and turrets.

In OMD: U it's slightly different. For starters theres only 2 lanes and the minions spawn from portals. Which must then travel from their portal from your base in to the enemy's rift. There's nothing for them to destroy once there, they simply must get in to the rift to score points. Once the enemy has lost all of their points your team wins. The minions must overcome traps (laid out by the enemy team heros) and guardians (which is a big dude in armor with powerful aoe attacks) which stand in front of gates.

Now heres the cool thing: you are free to customise what gets sent down the lane! There are 3 slots for front, middle and back positions. You can send everything from orcs which are numerous but not very tough and only worth 1 point each to giants which are big, tough but slow and I believe worth like 3-5 point each. You can also get dwarfs that cast protective shields or crossbow infantry that perforate heros and guardians from a distance. To get different minions to need to unlock thier cards which are crafted from materirals you get as you play the game or from chests (which can be bought with real money).

Your can also unlock different traps in this way and traits which are minor boosts to your hero. From bonus starting gold to slight increase in health or mana.

But thats for a 5v5 match Siege mode. If you're not feeling competitive theres a Survival co-op mode where you and up to 4 other people must endure several waves of minions.

Most people will complain about micro-transactions and whatnot but well thats how a free to game works I'm afraid. Do they expect that the poeple who work on this game work completely for free? Not to mention they are completely optional. Maybe if people focused more on the actual FUN of the game instead of grind this game might get more favourable reviews but I don't really want to get more in to that. If that's their opinion then so be it.

In short this game is really fun and even though it's in beta it's very well polished. And well it's completely free if you wish to at least try it out.

reviewText:
I love this franchise, and this game is not bad. I would had prefered a story mode and the ability to carry more traps, that is what made orcs must die fun. Thought there is so much, it feels so limiting cause of that paywall. Personally orcs must die 3 with a few dlcs sounds a lot better to digest. Aside from those complaints, the game is fun, and in the first few areas in survival there were times I was at the edge of my seat cause I couldn't lay enough traps or maybe traps in one area and the other 2 are open, which I see why people think of it as a MOBA.

Pros
The game is fun
A lot of trap options, though linited on how many you can carry
Going solo is a lot more intense in my opinion

cons
No story which is sad since I loved the humor
paywalls are never good and no one should defend them, especially if you are the type that complains avout dlc
Crafting is hit or miss, I personally like it but whats the point if you are limited to what you are able to carry

about my dlc comment
Do some math add everything you could buy in game with real money and then break it down to how many items usually come in an Orcs must Die game, And feel ripped off.

I kind of recommend the game even though I refuse to pay for anything that in 10 years the servers will go down and I lose my money

reviewText:
Product received for free

I have an incredibly extensive and large Steam Network, and have 10+ years on my other account.

During this time its possible I have never reviewed another game.

I played many of the Orc's Must Die series, and we all know how plagued they were with limited multiplayed features, and limited creativity.

I am glad to see they have FINALLY satisfied my need for an RPG.

I will go over the basics for all those that care, and are interested in this game. And I will start with the bad things.

Limited charaters at this point. Its scary to buy any champion because they are probably going to be in the free rotation soon. Most characters already in game feel very basic, and without pizaz.

This game is a MID GRADE MMO. That means if you are looking for anything beyond mid level customization, skins, and basic item unlocks, you should stop.

Character Customization? Easily more extenisve than most MOBA's, especially the free ones, but mid level feeling in the end.
Graphics? Excellent for the Orc's trilogy, mid level detail overall. Regarless= great effects and look.
Sounds? Absolutely hilarious the things you hear and the theme songs they implemented. Mid grade quality and synthisizing.
I think your getting the point.


Now lets continue to the PROS:

This game is absolutely hilarious. I mean the song the guy hums when you load into que makes me lol every time. ANd its not just a chuckle, like i actually start reflexing from my belly.

Many people have stated P2W, and P2P but that is NOT TRUE AT ALLLLLLLLLL. The correct terminology they are looking for is PAY TO PROCEED. If you want to play with your Level 50+ friends first day then sure, drop 50 bucks in the shop, get a whole bunch of chest, and enjoy.

The default farm rate of all items ingame seems legit. I mean its literally fresh open beta (as of cinco de mayo) so I get the feeling the developers want you get ur fair share of items so the game expands.

If you play 1 game a day? Can you proceed? (1 win) Yeah about every weekend I would guess that  you would have enough points to unlock one new trap, champion, guardian or whatever you choose. That seems fair since your not even grinding.

The community is amazing. I have played 20 hours so far, so about 20 games and only ONE game was someone toxic. It was still hilarious because the other players kinda just banded together and played around in the corner of the map.

This game is not a high stress game. You lose very little games while farming xp (thats right BONUS xp) in the survival area and the item drop rate seems very fair if not generous. I havent ventured into the siege mode (5 man vs 5 man) but I assume you would maintain a 50% win ratio there.

Lastly the largest PRO in my opinion is the ability to build your own trap/guardian/potion deck, which is entirely based on your creatitivy and farming capability. Isn't that what an MOBA is about?


In Conclusion:

I tried to answer some basic and broad questions, but I would 100% recommend downloading and playing this game maybe once a day to giggle intently at the loading que tune, and plenty of other hilarious, action packed and creative moments.

I guarantee end game playability will leave you a little bit hungry for more keys" (infinite survival map unlocks)
hoursPlayed: and diverse champions but remembering to enjoy the little things in life is what I believe Orc's Must Die is all about.\n\nAfterall its only open beta and they are doing a great job so far. Most of the hunger will be solved by periodic released of new champions

reviewText:
I purchased the OMD! franchise pack this last winter, and i am a huge fan of this series. well, i was. Until the release of this new istallment to the series. now, this game is Free-to-Play so i can't hate it too much. I played one match of each gamemode. I will break this into a list:

Pros:
Fast paced action like the rest of the series
Amazingly well thought out tower defense
Good Graphics (sometimes, it will be explained later)

Cons:
Bugs (EX. Getting killed by a orc that was walking above me, graphically)
graphical errors on nearly EVERYTHING
Pay to win features
zoomed out perspective (i'm just not a fan)
new restrictions (guardian placement; wall, ceiling, floor trap placement; etc.)
Difficulty (This is too easy!)
Lack of anti-cheat (the very first PVP match i joined, people were hacking)
Doesn't even get close to the quality of the series earlier installments
lack of options and optimizations

If you wanted a new OMD! sequel, this isn't it. This is a sad excuse for a game that could have been amazing. The oppritunity was there. They just could have done so much better.

2/10

reviewText:
Create a login!? WHY?! This is a Steam game. Why do I need to create another account to play your game?

This is a stupid gateway to get to your game. Use the platform that you're already on.

The first 2 games were great, but gameplay is always sacrificed under the free2play model. Robot Entertainment is showing a serious lack of innovation on this one. I loved the first 2 games so much. This game is those games, except that they slapped on a serious helping of Dungeon Defenders. If you like that sort of thing, I'm sure you'll love this one; but this feels like the developers were in a huge creative slump, so they took all of their traps from the first games, threw in a handful of new hero types, and decided to nickle and dime their players.

The tragedy is that the new maps are great, and make me want to play it. But, in order to make the game a MOBA, you're not really allowed to route the hordes in any meaningful ways. You're not allowed to block off any passages; sure, I get that, but what about blocking off passages that would route the hordes a different direction? Nope, can't do that. Because we want to milk the Dungeon Defenders cow. The second level had several spawn points for the hordes, so I tried to be creative and route them into a single killbox. Not allowed.

Sorry if I sound angry. I just know that the developers will make this their new money stream, and they won't make a truly gamer-focused experience, at least for the forseeable future. It's a shame.

reviewText:
Don't look at my steam played hours.  I've played 100s and 100s of hours between the alpha, closed beta, and open beta.  I never write steam reviews but I just felt compelled to write one for OMDU.  I'm a huge fan of OMD and OMD2.  And an even bigger fan of OMDU.

PROS:
• Survival Mode allows one to five people to group against minions.  This is very similar to OMD2 gameplay with a few main differences.  1) Unchained Meter which puts you into a crazy killing machine mode.  2) OMDU Heroes and bosses show up during the waves.  3) You can place guardians to help you.
• ENDLESS!  Just like in OMD2, you can play Endless in OMDU Survival after you reach a certain level.  It is SO MUCH FUN!  It is by far my favorite mode in the game and I want to play it all the time.  One to five man endless, with scoreboards and everything.  Go for combos and score, or go for the most waves on the scoreboard.
• The game is very balanced for being in Beta.  I'd love to see some tuning for Zoey who is a total boss in the right hands.  Any balance changes needed are fairly minor.
• The art is fun and playful.  The trait cards are hilarious as well as the loss game" art.  The maps are pretty as well.
• The humor is great.  The tutorials
recommended: and some of the character comments and jokes are so funny.\n• Siege can be played 5 v Bots (Siege Coop) or 5v5 (Siege PVP).  If you have two well matched teams
hoursPlayed: the games are so exciting

It's definitely not pay to win because the heroes are balanced and you won't lose just because you don't have a certain hero or trap or trait.  I find it funny that people are calling this pay to win.\n• Any trap upgrading and potions are only allowed in Survival games (PVE) so it doesn't affect PVP matches.  If you lose

and bosses.  It feels like almost every patch is unique and grand.

CONS:

reviewText:
In a market already saturated by great MOBAs OMDU falls flat.

There's no compelling reasons to choose OMDU over Smite, if you're looking for a 3rd person MOBA, or Heroes of the Storm, League of Legends, or DOTA2. Yes, there's traps, but they're so incidental to the gameplay that they're almost not even worth thinking about.

The traps, by necessity can't just outright slaughter waves as you'd expect from the game's sister titles. Counter to a traditional MOBA where mobs fight each other in lanes, in OMDU the traps are the only thing standing in the way of the mobs, and because once the traps are placed they're untouchable by the other team they serve merely to reduce pressure on one lane; you still have to run back to do something about the wave. This results in a large portion of the gameplay that simply doesn't feel good (not that you're given the space to design fun mazes even if it did).

Remove the traps from the equation and you're left with tepid, uninspired PvP that feels a pillowfight, floaty and not very impactful, and a leveling system that's easily unbalanced and makes it hard to recover if you're behind. There's simply no reason to choose OMDU over a more refined, better balanced MOBA at the moment.

reviewText:
Short version: With not enough Orcs Must Die to satisfy fans, and with so many better mobas out there, Orcs Must Die: Unchained offers little for either group.

Both Orcs Must Die and Dungeon Defenders are third-person character-based tower-defense series where the main enemy force is comprised of orcs, and both were infected by the moba virus some years ago. DD2 managed to realize the mistake it was making and pulled out of its tailspin, largely scrapping their game and starting fresh. OMD:U seems to have made the same realization, with its dramatic shift to putting in more PVE survival content, but the moba aspect remains, a milstone around the game's neck.

Traps and items suffer most in this transition. Where in OMD1 and 2 you could customize your favorite traps with special abilities, that feature is absent in Unchained. Absent too are several weapons. Wind Belt? Gone. Bone Amulet? Gone. Vampiric Gauntlets? Gone. Those items that remain are heavily curtailed from previous versions, and lack the interactions that made them fun. The Ice Amulet, for instance, now has a large cooldown attached to it, and there's no hammer in Unchained to score big damage against frozen ogres and trolls. It's understandable why these changes are made, but only because the game is beholden to its moba elements.

The survival mode is lacking, the grind is intense, and the series once beloved traps are sidelined. It's nice to see Robot trying to make some changes, but as of now OMD:U gets a stamp of avoid. Put it on the shelf with the other games in the last few years that tried to chase the moba rabbit and failed.

reviewText:
I have not played much of this game yet but I have had time to closely examine all the features in it and so far I have come up with some pros and cons.

Pros: All the gameplay, it feels great and works well in both survival and siege gamemodes.
The heroes, there are more heroes who each are very unique and creative.
The traps, traps are great and very diverse and also customizable with many options.
The crafting, the crafting has quite a nice feel and it is fairly easy to get crafting materials.

I could go on with pros but pretty much it is a well made game with the following exceptions/cons.

Cons: The way you get heroes takes quite a while with crafting and otherwise all you can do is buy them with real              money. You should be able to get heroes much easier because that is a huge part of the game.
The last con is the micro transactions, as all gamers know, they really mess up games when you get big spenders and along with micro transactions comes more difficulty to get items while not paying real money. I would really like to see most micro transactions taken out and to revert more to orcs must die 2 style where its much easier to buy items and heroes.


The reason I recommend the game is because it is in open beta and yet it has minimal bugs and runs smoothly and has content, so try the beta out and see what the devs will change and then make a decision to buy it or not when it comes out.

reviewText:
The grind is real (see bottom)

OK, so first you have to sign up for a Robot account with your email. Second, you have to find your friends all over again because it doesn't use the Steam system.

But that's not the worst part. The grind is real. I need hundreds more items before I can do my first crafting.  You have to play the same things over and over and over again.  This might not be so bad if you like PvP, which is what this is geared toward, but my preference is co-op. So my co-op partner and I have to do the same 3 levels over and over again to get to the point where we can craft items and get to the next level.

The game might be sort of OK if you are into PvP (but still not nearly as good as OMD2 as explained below).  A lot of the best things about it are only available in PvP, like the minion cards. But that just makes it worse for those of us who prefer solo or co-op play. You can see some cool things that you can't reach unless you are playing PvP.

Here's an example from OMD2.  In that game, you could buy archers and swordsmen and put set them up to help you with your traps.  You can't do that in SP or Co-op.  You get a single guardian, and when that guardian dies, it dies for all the upcoming waves too.

Another example of going backwards is that in OMD2, you had a lot of options of where to put traps and a huge variety of traps.  Trust me, you won't get nearly that many different traps in this game unless you put hundreds of hours into it or pay real money for upgrades. Also, there are small, clearly defined areas where you can put your traps.  You can't just place them anywhere. That glorious death march you sent enemies on during OMD2? Completely gone.

I feel what is at the heart of what is wrong with this game is the free-to-play model.  Much of the fun stuff is trapped behind paywalls. Sure, you can get it by grinding for hundreds of hours, but who wants to do that?  Literally, I'm not sure I've ever played a game that casually expects you to grind this much.  After 2 hours of play, I am not even close to crafting a single item of any type.  It's just too much.

This game is kind of fun for awhile, but overall very disappointing.

reviewText:
The short version is it's fun to play with friends and the versatility makes it a nice free game.

However, if you're in it for the long haul, crafting is a little unbalanced at this point, crafting heroes, traps, anything without spending money takes a long long time to farm, and because of this I have felt very restricted on what trap combinations to try out, as each trap I make stops me from making others.  The devs have been working on solutions to these problems and have done a great job so far, making heroes much more accessible, and they've done it all with no progress wipes.

Siege mode is a great take on MOBA pvp, although a surrender button would be appreciated, and Survival is still as great as it was in OMDU 1, but survival seems like the only real viable way to get any crafting materials to make new traps or items.

Even with it's shortcomings this is still a solid game with great gameplay, and I would recommend trying whether you're a fan of OMD or MOBAs

reviewText:
I'll make this quick and fast considering my last review for some dumb reason didnt post....

AS OF RECENT PATCH 1.2, GRIND HAS BEEN REDUCED BY ABOUT 60% Here's how--->

1. Recipes simplified ( They removed some resources from game, Ex. Kobold tears no longer exxist)

2.Amount of Resources required to craft things reduced

3. Now before the starting of the match you are able to pick ONE resource you want GURANTEED (You still will get other random resources at end of match too) to drop once you finish match. NOTE: Even if you lose you will still get resource (just not as much,also the amount you get is based on your performance during game)
+This allows crafting to be more focused on getting EXACTLY what you want,whenever you want.

4. IF you played BEFORE patch all resources you currently had that they have REMOVED from game will be CONVERTED INTO the NEW resources. Ex. Before patch i was unable to CRAFT any Traits,Minions, Bosses, Parts or Traps with my current resources AFTER conversion i was able  to craft 5 new traits i hadn't previously owned, 6 traps, 2 bosses, 4 minions, 8 Parts and 3 heroes (although i already had enough for bloodspike so 2 new heroes)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pros(+)
+Fun Gameplay (even with randoms)

+Now has that same old OMD feel with minimal Grind

+Enjoyable matchmaking (most of the time.... every game has its trolls and noobs)

+Variety of New and mostly Original chars that all have unique abilities that can help or support the team with direct roles

+Challenging

+ Friendly Community (Again mostly)

+Intuitive tutorial that teaches you pretty much everything (with ingame video clips that show you how something works/behaves before you buy them)

+Not p2w (EVERYTHING & ANYTHING is craftable except for Skins which have no impact on gameplay except maybe intimidation when u have a badass wolf in a pink frilly tutu on a with bows in its hair,ermm fur)

+Decent queue times

+Active moderators that will sometimes group up with players and actively play with people ingame and give tips and will answer anyquestion you may have( NOTE: there hasent been not ONE week were i havent seen at least one moderator or admin not play.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Cons(-)
-Not enough purchaseble skins (it rlly sucks that most skins are embedded in chest that have random drop chance even when buying highet tier that does guarantee a legendary but it may just be a resource or trait)

-Currently Only 2 different siege maps

-No Ingame Report button currently , must send ticket to report on  their website

-Games can be quite annoying when one of your team members are afk or disconnect during match, theres like a instant 70% chance you will lose (there needs to be away to somehow give the team a buff ( like a slightly reduced spawntime) or maybe have like the AI take over for that missing person(s)

| Overall 8.8/10 |

GIVE THE GAME A PROPER CHANCE BEFORE YOU LEAVE YOUR BS REVIEWS THIS GAME IS TRULY ENJOYABLE AND FUN TO PLAY WITH RANDOMS AND OR FRIENDS AND REMEMBER THE GRIND IS NOW MINIMAL****

reviewText:
I love Orcs Must Die. It's an excellent game. 2 was even better. But this? It murders it completely.

To be fair, there is some good to this. The multitude of different heroes adds a nice change - the lack of different character options in previous games was one of the downsides for me. The levels in this are also quite interesting, at least the few I've played.

But the cons far outweigh the pros for me here. For starters, cash shop. Minute those words come up, a game gets major down points with me. I knew about the CS in this before I'd even tried it, from other reviews, and it put me off trying it for a time. In the end, I decided to try it anyway. The CS isn't as bad as I'd expected - you can still get heroes and traps without paying by grinding for the items to craft them.

But.

Now, if it this was like the other games and purely PvE, this wouldn't be too much of an issue. Though some players would get the stuff faster, it wouldn't directly impact the play of F2P players much. It might even help somewhat if they're random matchups were with paid players, who'd be good help (in theory, anyway). The issue with it might be that paid players could get up leaderboards and the like easier, but that's not exactly the end of the world. But siege mode - which, as a concept, sounds fun - will be affected by the CS. Players who pay will be more powerful, and more than likely mash the free players into the ground. Fair? Not so much. By which I mean, not at all. If you intend to do more than the PvE on it, it's Pay to Win. Or at least Pay-to-have-a-hugely-overwhelming-advantage.

But the cash shop isn't the only issue I take with this game. For one thing, because the matches are on servers, that means the servers run even if the players aren't all ready yet. I've played single player, because I'm not really one for putting up with random groups - I tend to get the players who'd fight each other as much as the orcs (not literally, but you get the idea). But if the match takes time to load, sometimes you end up in the match which has already progressed to the point where orcs are pouring through the rift you haven't had time to defend at all. Not so helpful.

Another thing is that the traps, whilst useful, just don't seem to have the effectiveness that they'd had in previous games. Half, usually more, of the fighting that goes on in matches seems to fall down to my character and guardians. Part of this is due to the traps themselves seeming a little on the weak side, but also partly due to the way the orcs spawn. They tend to come at you in huge groups that your traps simply cannot handle, whereas in the previous games the waves were more spread out, so at least your traps had time to reset before more orcs came at them.

Whilst there's a chance this game could improve, at the current time, I wouldn't suggest this game to people. You're better off buying 1 and 2.

reviewText:
Review time: Little over 3 hours
Play time: PvE / PvP
Level: 15

(Note, a review time of 3 hours to get an impression of a game is well in the resonable area)

Pros:
-The game looks wonderful, runs great
-Clean UI, simple to use button layout
-Queue system is smooth
-Built in communication works well
-Items shown clearly on how they are obtained

Cons:
-Game has been stripped down and sold off to the cash shop
-Crafting is based on pure RNG and luck
-Item Crafting is limited to PVP and PVE sets, these do not cross over thus it takes double the time
-Items are built up so the chance of obtaining them is very low
-Advancing your hero takes simply too long, you will go long periods without seeing any at all unless RNG is on your side
-Hero Selection is done after being matched up, so trying to advance one hero is limited to those you play with


Final stance:
If the game continues to grow I will return to take another look. I have been a large fan of the series for awhile and was looking forward to this game because I'd enjoy it more with more friends being able to play. But due to the limited settings and RNG ontop of RNG I will not be recommending this game at this time. I enjoy my time in games, and as an educated gamer understand that time itself does not make a game great, it's what you do in that time. In order to play well and have fun I am required to grind endlessly just to get the basic loadout, let alone advance.

I have no issues helping and funding games that show they are there to be entertaining, but I wont open my wallet for those tha simply do it out of greed.

If the RNG goes down and the game has better options to fund it. (Such as a buy option for say 30-40 that opens the entire game up) then I'll be happy to help fund there work, but nickle and dime tatics simply don't work on seasoned players.

reviewText:
I normally don't write reviews (or criticism to others), but I've been seeing a LOT of unfair reviews for this game, so here goes.

Many people have written bad reviews based solely on the partnership with Gameforge as a publisher, but giving a great game a bad review because of the publisher is rediculous.

Also, many people have complained that this game is a MOBA. That's also rediculous, because that is ONE game mode. Besides, it's very fun and hardly feels standard. Choosing which minions to send and structuring your defenses makes it feel more like a Tug of War.

I've also seen the complaint that it's pay to win. Yes and No. If hearthstone and league of legends is pay to win, then yes, you would also see this as pay to win. You start with a standard deck that once modified with a few cards, is really solid.
If the argument is that the grind is too high, then I disagree. Maybe it is too high for PvE (survival), but that is because there are Trap Tiers and consumerables. On the other hand for PvP (siege), after 30 or 40 hours you will have multiple layouts/decks. The prices are so low, that they are comparable to F2P shooter games that lend you the cards except, here you permanently get them.
They are still adjusting prices, they already wrote hero prices will be changed next patch. Besides, spending a few $/€/£ is perfectly okay, not every game feels that can use Dota 2's income model and get away with it.There are currently some technical issues and the playbase is not high enough to instantly find games 5 AM on a weekday ¯\_(ツ)_/¯. However, I am not going to badly rate a very fun, solid, new, and original game low based on that.

TL;DR: It's free and fun.
5/7 - Looking forward to seeing this develop.

Btw, they currently have a referral program that rewards players that sign up with one. About the same as 2 cheap heroes. If you know anybody that plays it then they have a link, you could create 2 accounts, or if all else fails you could use mine.

Here:  http://en.omd.gameforge.com/registration.html?refbyfriend=0e1db7cf-f5b8-11e5-a83f-c81f66b90a86

reviewText:
Not dubbed Orcs Must Die 3, and for good reason: It isn't.

It's slower, much more restrictive, less dynamic, and despite its obviously high production values, it lacks the essential feel and character of its predecessors. Basic minions (or creeps) are small and nigh faceless 'bullet sponges,' you can only place traps in blue areas, there's a limit to how many traps you can field, and you gather resources to craft basic items and upgrades. Or you could do what Robot Entertainment would rather you do and pay for the upgrades, heroes, and skins with real money in their cash shop.

This game may mean the end of the Orcs Must Die franchise as it has been known, as an authentic sequel would take away from what its developers are trying to do here: get rich quick or go broke in this modern MOBA gold rush.

Fans of classic OMD need not apply. You won't find much of what you loved in the originals under this game's hood except for the conspicuously familiar coat of paint that clashes jarringly with its unfulfilling gameplay.

Play OMD 2 instead, enjoy it, and long for the 4 player cooperative winner this game could have been.

reviewText:
Put over a hundred hours into OMD2. Not a big MOBA person so was a bit worried at first with OMDU.  Survival in OMDU though is awesome.  If you're new to the series and just attack it as a brawler or like a MOBA in Survival, you're in for a rough ride.  But when you get with a group of strangers having to improvise a killbox together, putting all the tricks together (different traps to combo, killing in killbox to combo, creative walling to delay waves on one side so you can rotate over later, etc.) it is awesome.

After getting a perfect score on the hardest difficulty on all the levels in OMD2, I had gotten used to the carefully planned killboxes, knowing exactly what was coming every wave.  With the random minions/doors each wave, the improvisation and cooperation really make OMDU Survival mode a standout.

If you're a MOBA fan, I haven't tried much siege mode as it's not my cup of tea.  I can guarantee that it is different than any other MOBA you've tried. This isn't a LoL/Dota clone.

If you've never tried an OMD game, there's a bit of a learning curve on Survival, but the community is friendly and there's nothing more satisfying than beating an especially hard match.

If you're an OMD1/2 fan, matchmaking will take away a lot of the control you're used to.  You'll also have to be patient about unlocking some of your favorite traps.  Still, the new heroes (omg, all the smolder damage with her unique trap), more traps, more types of enemies and supersize maps make OMDU Survival something special.

reviewText:
This game is really really fun.

I think anyone who enjoys competitive multiplayer should give this game a try, but I understand if you are afraid of a F2P format with an item shop. I have a lot of hours loged into this game counting my time in closed beta, and I have never felt that it was pay 2 win. The item mall allows you to buy heroes, skins, and consumables for PvE.

Heroes are on free rotation and can be crafted after some time. At about 20ish games into the open beta I can craft 2 heroes if one of them belonged to the most expensive category, more if not. Skins are just cosmetic and offer no other bonus. Consumables are used in a PvE game mode and are earned during normal gameplay, they can not be used in PvP. You can also buy a RNG box that could drop anything in the game, this can give you a nice item or materials to build items  but these boxes are also given to you free each month and drop randomly after any game.

With that out of the way if this style of game inerests you at all give it a try. Its free! Play a few rounds and see if this take on the genre is to your liking!

reviewText:
My Review after over 10 hours of playing this symphony of fun and frustration:

First of all the game is still in development (beta) so of course there are bugs and all the well known things (lags, sound suddenly stops, ...) in the game. This does not count as a con like the developers are going to change and improve the game.

So when we leave all the bugs away I would say it is a very nice version of Orcs Must Die!" with a very high potential.

- There is still the well known rift defending mode where you need to kill all the enemys before they get to your rift/s. It is new that you can now play all modes and missions with up to 4 other players. (friends or just anyone)

- The new mode "Conquer" (I hope its the right translation) feels very much like "League of Legends". Here you can either play against NPC's or other players trying to take over the enemys rift. The tricky thing is that your team needs to defend and attack at the same time. Of course you defend with your character and loads of traps. Attacking you do with spawning troops of orcs
recommended: leading them through the enemys traps
hoursPlayed: killing the badass guards and gates until your troops can enter the enemys rift. Furthermore there are (like in "LoL" too) specific side tasks to do (depending on the map) which allows you to send in a boss with your troops once per task.\n\n- What surprised me pretty much is that they built an ingame shop where you can buy new characters or equipment for real money. Of course you can chraft everything you can buy in this shop
voteText: but this needs a lot of time searching for the specific loot. But still I hate games with shops where you need your debit card. Anyways I cross my fingers hoping that they will take it out again. I more like paying for the game instead of geting it for free and then paying ingame for all kind of stuff. But I guess im not the only one with the opinion. ;)\n\nHowever
