reviewText:
MY REVIEW:

I really don't like MOBA's, they bore me and I have tried many many MOBA's, almost all of the popular ones and could not find a interest in most of them.  But this game, this game I find a lot of joy in because you can choose to run with the minions, set up traps and defenses, or run around the map and assassinate enemy players.  It almost doesn't even feel like a MOBA, it just feels like a very fun tower defense game.  I enjoy the game's concept, needs better players/teamwork play.

MY PERSONAL COMPLAINTS:

These are very small complaints, not very much complaints but things I wish were in the game.  If someone leaves on the team, you are bound to lose, I really hope they add smart AI to fight for the disconnected and not bots that will end up feeding the enemy. Another thing is that maybe the developers could add in an option to offset the character from the camera as it blocks some of the things you can't see, doesn't really effect how you play but it is just annoying to see.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys tower defense elements in a fun and cooperative MOBA environment.
There are two different modes to this game, one pve oriented and one pvp. The pvp is a lot of fun and engaging. Teamwork is definitely required to win and having to place traps and create a killbox in a pvp game is a lot of fun. Traps add a lot to the MOBA environment. Obviously there are your many damage traps, but there are also ones like a speed pad that gives you a burst of speed, mana wells, damage power ups, all sorts of different things that encourage you to think tactfully if you want to win. There also seems to be a lack of a meta and I have had good success with many different types of traps and heroes played in many different roles.

I have only played a little of the pve in this game because the pvp mode is just way more fun. But it isn't as trap heavy as the previous games and put more importance on creating killboxes so you can increase your money gain and killing things yourself rather than letting the traps do all the work. Overall still pretty fun, just hard to pull myself away from that pvp mode.

The downsides are things you would expect from a newer game, longer queue times once your mmr gets up there (10 minutes on average) and the matchmaking can be a little weird at times. All of which could probably be solved by having a larger player base, which will inevitably get larger since the open beta just started recently.

reviewText:
Interesting defence game that focuses both on Heroes as well as Traps, instead of the conventional Towers. Fun gameplay, but can be grindy if played too frequently in a short span of time.

Pros:
- Lots of traps to allow players a variety of options and sets to build their minion killers
- Multiple heroes for multiple playstyles, each with its own design and personality
- Fun gameplay, interesting mechanics
- Free to play
- Feels quite balanced

Cons:
- Siege mode feels a little stale, you lead a troops to battle, but it doesn't feel like you are doing much, especially newer players
- In game costs are moderately high, so it takes a while to grind for F2P
- Few maps that are being recycled with increased difficulty

reviewText: If you like Tower Defense games or MOBAs, this is a game you should definitely try. It's in beta right now, but all progress you make in the game will carry over into release. I have been enjoying the game so far, but I don't see the fun lasting long in it's current state. (Barricades Must Die) There are lots of problems I've seen already, between the unfun and unnecessary grind for materials and loot rewards for leveling up or finishing a game, and the later levels in Survival mode, taking up to 50 minutes to complete, with no option to pause the game and the time constraints between waves, where you, yourself have to run all over the map to loot every single item that drops before the next wave comes or risk losing it. In Siege mode, especially against other players, where games can take up to an hour to complete, I do not feel like the material rewards justify the time investment, though the game mode is extremely well done and fun otherwise.\n\nI feel like some changes they are making already are both good and bad. I see a lot of issues that could potentially ruin the game with them having specific siege" heroes vs "survival" heroes
date: almost forcing people to play certain heroes in the different game modes
hoursPlayed: I've enjoyed the game but definitely feel they have their hands full with balancing the game between the two game modes and either making the material grind easier
voteText: or at least make it feel more optional to take on the higher level maps with less upgraded traps. I will look forward to seeing what they do with the game and will definitely play A LOT more when they tackle some of these issues. Good and fun Co-op gameplay that just needs some minor tweaks!"

reviewText:
OMD!U had a rocky start. The first part of the game was devloped to be more like a MOBA with OMD traps, orcs and heroes. It was lacking refinement and was nothing like old OMD.

However, as time went on the team implemented the survival mode back into the game, with this, a new chapter of OMD!U began. Right now survival mode is very close to its former glory with loads of maps designed specificly with the OMD style and system in mind, with more on the way! the PvP MOBA mode had undergone massive changes and now stands as a strong contender in the market with many unqiue OMD features. The only thing I would say is that the hero roster right now is quite small however this is becase many chracters were removed to be reworked. Real dedication on the devlopers part.

Overall OMD!U is shaping up to be a fantastic game and in time the survival will return to the loftly heights of OMD 2

reviewText:
First off I have to say I was a HUGE fan of Orcs Must Die 1 and 2 and was worried about how this new one would turn out. Free to play and with player vs player moba style mode? Not what I was hoping for! But they have really improved things over the las tyear. I played over 100 hours of this game during the closed beta over the last year.

Was expecting crap but this has turned out much better than I was expecting so far. I really ho pepeople give this game a proper chance as in more than just a few minutes. Especially old fans of the first two games, give this one a proper try please!

They started off with just player vs player with a moba style mode, but during this last year they have started to add PvE aspect to, sort of like the previous games Endless modes, sort of a survival style. I also hear more pve options are on the way as the game keeps getting worked on.

It is not perfect and I was expecting the worst, but after giving it a bunch of time adn seeing the game improved over the last year, I am pretty impressed with the game and the improvements the devs have done lately.

Do me a favor and atleast give this game a try, it is one of the few free to play games that I enjoy, I have not once felt like I had to spend real money on this game, over the last year it has been no problem to get items and traps just by playing the game. Still some work to do on things just as AI and hopefully they continue to add more to the PVE aspects, but this is a much better start than i was expecting! Also nice to see it is on steam now finally, which will bring it to more gamers, I just hope people give it a proper chance and stick with the game as it is being worked on and improved. I thought the worst, but have been surprised with its progress so far. The game offers some PVE and some PVP, check them both out and maybe see you online!

reviewText:
In the games current state, I can not recommend it to other people. Starting off in the game is fun and you get a lot of excitement. Unfortunately once you get to the higher levels you'll notice that you rarely get full matches (for Survival) anymore. This is due to the games 'level range' system in which a player who is level 15 cannot be in a match with someone who is level 30. Because map levels don't scale to the average level you're stuck in a match of 2s or 3s as you progress over level 40.

Also, there's a ton of bugs and glitches that came with the games latest patch. Once bug in Seige is when the enemy bots go to their minion portal, they always manage to get stuck staring at it. I can not say how many bots I've killed because they were unresponsive. There's also been times the bots would stand too long and the game would kick them out. Falty system to kick your own bots from a match.

Occassionally you'll have a bot that gets stuck in mid-air and will just stay there the entire game. If they're ranged, they'll shoot at you. If they melee, they'll stand and get kicked.

I would really like to see these issues addressed and fixed so I may edit my review in the future.

reviewText:
Im played both OMD 1 & 2 and OMDU since the early closed beta over gameforge.

The game has still a long way to go to feel like the other but it is on its way.

+ Balancing of the Minions is pretty good.
+ Most fun with friends as always.
+ Free2Play and in my eyes not Pay2Win

- Matchmaking needs still improving especially when the level different between players is to big.(15-20 level)
- Most players seem to be pretty dumb since they ignore the chat, pings and obvious map designs.
- The required materials for crafting r still pretty high and for a new hero you have to farm at least a month.
- Daily Login dont seem to make much sense when 6 Days log in give you 600 Skulls and 16 Days give you 250.
- Same goes with dailys. 1000 Minion kills for 600 Skulls and 25 Hero kills/assists for 250.
- Its very weird programmed and after launching a window with pretty low resolutions launches and after selecting a level the actual game starts with normal one.

All in all i recomment it for friends who enjoyed the previous titles. Give it time though ;)

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying OMD1 is my 3rd favourite game of all time.  It struck a perfect balance between trap and player damage, allowing you to create a great kill box and sit back, a decent one and pick up the slack with player damage, or just kite your way to victory with pure player damage.  Absolute brilliant game & level design.

OMD2 faired less well.  They shifted the focus to players being required to do most of the damage and traps were just there to help out a bit.

OMDU is complete and utter garbage.  Not only did they take the OMD2 model and make it even more about player damage, especially with patch 1.2, they had the absolutely idiotic design choice of forcing players to stick in place for a time before they can attack.  That's right, no kite killing, no chasing down an enemy bashing at it... you have to get out in front of them and stop, wait, and then attack as they run by you yet again.  The player has literally become another stuck in place trap that can be run around.  Add to this the 'free-2-pay-more' greed, a focus on adding needless shrubery to the environment, painfully bad map design for kill boxing/multi-level gaming/pathing or any type of real creativity, no campaign, a crazy number of bugs for a Beta, and recycled audio... this game is the biggest disappointment of recent memory.

Robot Entertainment has alienated a fan today.

reviewText:
Yes, microtransactions suck. Yes, I don't trust Gameforge either. Yes, most MOBAs that aren't LoL or DotA2 fail miserably.

That said, if you liked Orcs Must Die 1 and 2, check this out nevertheless. No one forces you to play the MOBA mode. There is a normal survival mode in there aswell. You can play it solo, duo or with up to 5 friends or strangers. And yeah, so far I've had fun with it. And after you've probably actually had some fun aswell, do try the MOBA mode once, surprisingly enough it actually works quite well, feeling like a mixture of normal OMD and Smite.
Can't say much about how fair it is in terms of f2p or how balanced Siege (MOBA) is, but if you're here (like I was originally) for the classic OMD experience, give it a chance. It's free, so why not?

reviewText:
I feel like this game is getting a lot of semi-underserved hate for not just being more of the same ol' OMD (and some deserved hate for the F2P elements)! It's resigned to be a 5 player co-op experience, and a 5v5 competitive experience. If you've played the previous games and are wondering about this one, here's what you should know...

--Classic Gameplay--
The classic defending against waves" format is back in the form of Survival Mode. With this you can team up with up to four other players to defend against waves of enemies. The places you can construct traps are a little more restrictive
date: and the traps don't quuuiiite have the pop they did in previous games. This is because
hoursPlayed: there's 5 of you. That's a lot of firepower from the heroes
voteText: so the traps seem more toned down. Still
helpfulPercent: they are essential
votesHelpful: and plenty of fun. Most of all
votesTotal: it's a lot of fun to actually get to play OMD with more than just 1 friend
votesFunny:
and I think overall the mode feels balanced and is a lot of fun...with friends you know. Random groups...less so.

--Siege Mode--
This is the competitive 5v5 mode. It is very similar to a MOBA like DOTA2 or LOL
commentsCount: but also pretty damn different. There are still traps and minions
column16: but now each team is leading their own minions to their enemy's rift. It'd be hard to explain everything
column17: but you gain points to power up your portal(s)
column18: allowing your team to summon better and better minions (which you get to choose just like your traps). Each hero has really well defined strengths
column19: and you even chose your roll before the match starts
column20: giving you actual bonuses based on what you intend to do. Compared to most MOBAs it's pretty simple
column21:
but the added tower defense mechanics make it a surprising amount of fun once you get into it.

--Unlockables--
I think this is a sticking point for a lot of people. This game is F2P
column22: so prepare for microtransactions. You can certainly get by without paying anything
column23: and you'll still be able to eventually unlock every hero
column26: and item. But it's fairly slow going. After the tutorials and about 5 siege matches I managed to unlock 2 traps
column29: that's pretty much it. Unlocking heroes  take forever
column30: and there are only 5 free heroes in rotation at a time (out of like...12
column32: not a huge deal). The real kicker is unlocking items requires the classic skulls...AND materials
column33: of which there are a pretty big variety. They drop randomly during matches
column36: buuut if you aren't lucky it might take forever to get the Radiant Gears you need to get that new trap. Plus traps/items/minions are rated by rarity
column37: and the rarer ones require even harder to get items. What's worse
column40: minions or items. You can just buy chests that MIGHT contian the materials you need. It's an ok system if you plan to play a lot
column41: because it'll give you a lot to constantly strive for
column42: but for a lot of people I can see this being a deal breaker. Frankly
column43: I don't blame you if it is.\n\nTLDR; It's different than the previous OMD games
column44: but there's a lot to love here. The gameplay is exactly what it needs to be. However
column45: if not for that great gameplay
column46: the grind required for unlocking all those sweet traps/minions/items would be almost unforgivable."

reviewText: I just want to say ... This is very enjoyable and entertaining game. I’ve read a couple reviews that say its buy to win or are complaining about the micro purchases. I wanted to clear something up.  Everything in the game play and mechanics that allow for buffs, bonuses, upgrades, additional traps, heroes or minions are all attainable through normal game play without spending money.  you may buy in game currency to purchase heroes that are not guest" heroes (these seem to change regularly so the chance to play any one hero for free is very likely given enough time) you may also purchases chests (they can be randomly obtained by completing rounds in game) and you can purchase any in game items or crafting material as well this would allow you to obtain things faster but the devs have done a good job to prevent people from just buying everything you can't craft upgrades  for traps and items until your level increases to certain level the first currently is unlocked at level 25 which means you can own all the crafting materials in the world but you can't upgrade until you have played the game enough to reach that level.\nCO-OP game play is awesome and the 5v5 concept is really cool… my friends and I have a blast playing it. … good job and congrats to devs … on par for another great release. It builds on the previous franchise titles adding depth and more re-play ability …… well done.\n"

reviewText:
Friend convinced me to try it. i played a few rounds, the tutorial, and right from the get go i could tell i would hate it. and the entire time i played it i felt nothing but an overwhelming sense of apathy and hatred the entire time.

The reason? This... this is not orcs must die. It has a couple of characters from orcs must die, and the monsters are from orcs must die... but that's really about it...

Orcs-must-die is a fast-paced beatemup-survival type towerdefence game where nearly endless waves of monsters rush at you at once, each trying to reach the mcguffin you are defending with your life, forcing you to rely on your quick-thinking, fast reflexes, and powerful weapons, traps, and spells to defeat them.

Orcs-must-die is placing a new barricade directly behind a barricade that's seconds away from being destroyed and placing twice as many traps to defend it mid-round. it's placing three paladins down in a row in the middle of the hallway while four archers and two dwarves cover them from the platform above. Orcs-must-die is rapidly spam-clicking your bladestaff for a hithithithithithithithit on twenty enemies at once before swapping to your blunderbus or acid bombs to take out the flying units above you. Orcs must die is carefully picking the spells, weapons, traps, and guardians you want at your side, and upgrading them in a way that suits you best and makes them do the job you need them to do.

In this? Well for one thing I’ve tried three different heroes (one even being described as a fast-hit-and-run type) and not once did i ever experience the rapid-fire attacks of the beautiful OMD2. not once did i ever feel i got more then one attack in every two seconds. Not once was i given directions or information on how to look through my traps, learn about what they do, and pick which ones i want to use after upgrading them to my liking. And you can only place one paladin down and only in very specific spots? WTF? where are the archers or the dwarves? I have a huge-♥♥♥ hallway to defend here, why can't i have two or three paladins standing here defending it rather then lazing back where i don't need them?? Where are my spells? where are my multitude of magical weapons? Hell, here's a big one. Where the hell is the plot? or the character interaction? Orcs must die 2 had over twenty different levels, each with the warmage, sorceress, and archmage talking to and bantering off one another the whole time, giving the world a feeling of immersion and interest! Oh, and hey, here's another big one. Where the hell are the endless hordes of orcs! That's kind of the whole point! I've seen at most ten or twenty at once? And what's with the heroes? you don't need heroes! Gnolls, Trolls, and Ogres! THOSE are the big bads you need to look out for! Introducing enemy heroes you need to worry about does nothing but add more tediousness to an already terible MOBA blasphemy of a great brand!

This? This is just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ DOTA rippoff. This is not orcs must die. this makes me sick.

Will i try it again? Possibly. I made a deal to try it again with a friend of mine who thinks it's really good after we beat orcs must die 2 together. will playing it more change my mind? Probably not. But I’m willing to give it a go.

Robot Entertainment. You had a perfect game with orcs must die 2, and i will forever love you for it. it had a great plot, amazing gameplay, funny characters, and a satisfying ending. you could have left the franchise there and it would be good. I can only hope that if you ever plan on making any more orcs must die games, you realize the mistake that unchained was and go back to the formula that was perfection.


p.s. what's this about the war mage having a crush on someone called the disciple? What nonsense is this? War mage X Sorceress for life.

reviewText:
Do you like killing orcs? course you do. If you don't, maybe you'll like killing bears. Doesn't really matter. If you like horde killing with buddies, you'll love this game. This is one of my favorite game series, and I beat both of the first two. With more heroes and different unique mechanics for each, it makes playing co-op that much more appealing to everyone. However, I am sad there is no bladestaff weapon character, as it was my favorite setup in OMD2. I'm looking forward to more characters, more enemies and more laughs. This could quickly become my most played game on steam, right above KF. Traps, accessability, progression, cards, crafting. It has a variety of features, although I would recommend robot give everyone enough materials to purchase a single hero, just to get started. Especially if you have a bunch more heroes planned. Everyone needs a starting point. Or you could go the LoL route and rotate free heroes.

Bottom line, F2P, fun, fresh, humorous with a ton of potential, in both playstyle customization and map variety.

I rate: Try it, support the devs if you like it.
No actual rating until the game releases fully.

reviewText:
The first thing i'd like to state is that i played in the closed beta on Gameforge so dont mind my steam playtime now lets start my review

The game has come a long way ever since the early closed beta i participated in i remember back then even on max graphics the textures were very blurry and low quality and the optimization was not that good over time they added the higher graphics and more modes , heroes and everything at the cost of worse optimization which was a bit bad however its to be expected of closed beta i recently stopped playing when they added the playing time on days which was near the end and now in open beta i'd like to say the game has become much better here are some pros and cons:

Pros
-Great Graphics
-Fun to play
-Supports Co-Op if you dont like pvp
-Good Optimization
-Fun quest system
-Good and hilariously voice acted tutorials
-Can get everything for free except skins ( you can get some promo ones for free though)
-Fun Crafting System

Cons
-New players will call the game pay to win instantly after seeing money for chests
-Gold is expensive
-Will require a BIT of grinding not too much
-Player level difference in PvP the game needs some updates on matchmaking

Overall the game is good very good for those of you in the reviews whining omg you need gold for some chests?! Pay2WinPay2win! It's not... you can actually get even those store chests for FREE from daily login rewards which DO reset i believe so you can easily get everyting plus even the chests dont guarantee the items you literally need for crafting and it is YOUR choice if you either want to pay money to speed up the material gathering process or to instantly buy a hero dont forget that out of the 12 heroes 5 of them are on a rotation EVERY week and you dont need to own every one just the ones you like.Whoever has played orcs must die or is new to the series should try the game it's free you have nothing to lose

reviewText:
PROS:
-Runs great, even with older machines
-No technical or connection problems
-Beautiful character design and graphics
-Hilarious voice acting and character interactions
-Fun gameplay that feels different game-to-game and hero-to-hero
-Deep progression system to keep you upgrading and setting goals
-PVE mode is just like oldschool high-score-chasing OMD
-PVP mode is a refreshing take on MOBAs, which is actually a TOBA (Tower Online Battle Arena)
-PVP also feels very different compared to other games (it has a strategic third person Warcraft mod feeling)
-5 player PVE!
-5v5 player PVP!

CONS:
-Crafting system isn't easy to understand
-Too many materials in the crafting system
-Needs more maps and heroes for a lot of diversity
-Hard to visualize progression through unlocking, ugrading, and leveling traps and heroes with the crafting system
-The above can be easily adjusted with patches - all the hard technical stuff is already figured out

reviewText:
http://en.omd.gameforge.com/registration.html?refbyfriend=0f238baf-f5b8-11e5-a83f-c81f66b90a86


There are rewards for you if you are recruited by me:
http://en.omd.gameforge.com/account.html

Is it pay to win?

As I'm writing this review, I am just over 20 hours into the game. I've won over 20 matches, more than I've lost, I've added 3-4 traps to my itinerary, some rare, I've crafted two ability item thingies, I've crafted two trait cards and need one more to have a full deck of my own customization and I've crafted a war mage. So pay to win, I don't really think so, I haven't spent a penny. Answer: NO!

CO-OP?

This game is really about teamwork, from the beginning if you don't agree with your team mates as of which hero each of you is going to use, who defends, who attacks and who pillages, then inevitable failure is near. This is not DOTA 2 or league of legends, although it has elements of these lane pushing games. This is also Orcs Must Die, a tower defense action game. Keep in mind I mainly play siege PVP. YES!

Can smart people and dumb people play it?

It is easy to learn, my friend coached a new member of our team as of what to do and we won, despite having this newbie on our team, who at first was playing very badly and my friend told him so. By the end of the game and at our victory, he knew what to do, and in fact had collected the steak and cooked it to spawn our boss minion. But this game takes time to master, there are melee and ranged characters, with strengths, weaknesses and unique abilities, in my opinion the game is masterfully balanced, these developers know what they are doing. Some characters require more strategy, some are just ravagers, all are fun to play with and in my experience, each one caters to a different playstyle. YES!

Is it cool and funny?

Damn yes, this is a funky and funny game, just as much as the other Orcs Must Die games. It's wickedly cool, characters are hillarious, and seeing orcs dismembered, well, that's a matter of taste.

UPDATE! 70 hours in, I'm almost at level 80 (75), I have unlocked two warmages, StinkEye and BlackPaw, upgraded a trap, have loads of resources and am having lots of fun. I've won 61 matches. I love this game.

I think the negative reviews come from people who know the game is in beta and just want the developers to give away more goodies. The way I see it they've been very generous already, it's a shame people have that attitude, give an inch, take a mile. Because, I hope it doesn't put people of playing the game. My opinion, try it for yourself.

(One suggestion, please allow players to place guardians in siege, that would be awesome!)

UPDATE! 100 hours in on steam, and about 50 hours in on Gameforge. I love this game! What can I say, it is so addictive. Siege PVP is where I play the most, although upgrading traps in survival is cool and fun. I just love the team work, I love the way the games laid out, if you are starting, try pillaging, because you don't really need great minions or traps for that. Once you get better and have better minions attack, Once you have really got the hang of the game and have nice traps defend. Don't just run around and then complain about the game. I enjoy this game so much more than Dota 2 and I believe it is deeper and more strategic. This game is not just a gem, it is the Pink Panther baseball sized diamond!

So I'm 160 hours into this game, just on this account, about 100 on the gameforge account. I love this game so much I bought the Ultimate Pack, just to support the developers. Thank you for all the fun!

reviewText:
If you loved Orcs Must Die! then...you might not like this.

As far as a moba-esque game it seems okay, but I don't play the series just to play another Moba. A lot of the gameplay seems to sort of be there, but it feels more weighted down. Movement feels much more clunky and the fun of being able to run around in battles is much less exciting and rewarding. Things feels more condensed and even traps are much less impressive.

This seems to be because some things had to be balanced, de-emphasized or made a bit faster. It makes sense for the type of game because it is now more focused on multiplayer. However this takes out much of the charm the other two games have had for me.

So in summary: If you are looking for Orcs Must Die gameplay, this game only sort of delivers. It has a different purpose, and I'm sure it's good for people who like that. But for me? I'm going to take a pass. I hope they do another game more like the other two in the future.

reviewText:
Few days ago, I made a negative review for the game. Not because the game is absolute trash but because for a F2P game, it was too heavy grind. I would have not called this P2W game as half the game is just coop and the PvP part of the game is not affected by trap upgrades and stuff like that. It's pretty much impossible for a player to pay and make the PvP unfair for those who didnt pay. But the game was feeling like a P2P because it was so long to unlock something that most people would have been disgusted before even starting to grind. Add to this the heroes and traps feel weak and the rewards for playing/leveling were not awesome. It was the perfect conditions to make this game a complete fail because only the hardcore fans, who can stand heavy grinding, would have played.

I have to admit I was very surprised how fast the devs reacted to massive complains about insane grinding. They quickly adjusted rewards for leveling, changed missions so they are not too painful and boring to do (those missions were forcing you to play a given hero and people that were not able to get their hero at beginning of the game were just rage quitting to queue again, mehhh!!). So yeah, not only surprised but impressed too. They proven they were ready to listen and bring some change to keep a good playerbase which is good. The game is not easy, you still have to grind but the grind is fair. You can unlock a new hero pretty quickly compared to before. Honestly, I think it's fair.

Now let's give the good and the bad of this game:

PROS:
- PvE and PvP (everyone will be happy!!!)
- PvE up to 5 players in coop
- Progress thru crafting
- lot of heroes VS only 2 in the OMD 1/2
- Trap upgrades are not available in PvP
- Free rotations of heroes (seems to change every week??)
- Daily quests + missions + daily rewards
- Devs seems to care about feedback as they made tons of changes since the open beta

CONS:
- Grinding required but never as heavy as it was at the beta release
- Survival (same mode as OMD 1 and 2) is not feeling as awesome as the previous games


Honestly, I like very much the idea behind the PvP and the fact that there is no trap upgrades allowed in PvP. This way, if you just unlocked traps you are as strong as a player that would have played so much hours that he would have all his traps to tier 3. And crafting a trap is much much more easier than upgrading them. So I believe it makes the P2W pretty much impossible and it keeps the game fair. A newcomer as equal chances to wreck than a long time player. Also, it's pretty easy to buy new minions so again, games wont be completely unbalanced and unfair for new players. The only issue that could happen is the balance of heroes. But this is true in almost every games like League of Legends, Dota, etc. Hero balance will be the hardest part. I hope they are going to work hard on this and listen carefuly to players review. But What I heard is like 5-6 heroes were removed from the open beta due to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ balance. They wanted to rework them before releasing them again when they would be less OP. I hope it's true because that would be just perfect to me.

The survival is the same mode as OMD 1 and 2. The traps and heroes feel weak at beginning. It's due to the fact you level up quifckly and you need to upgrade traps which take alot of time. It's going to be the hardest part. If you are playing with friends and splitting the duty of upgrading traps, it can helps alot. Also, some heroes feel weak at first but synergized very well with some traps or other heroes. This will be your job to discover the best combos and how to reveal the power of every hero. But so far, I seen some heroes I was considering poop being useful in unexpected ways.

I honestly think that when you're done upgrading your traps, the surivval mod looks like OMD 1 and 2 but more challenging as it is a 5 man coop (harder to coordinate a bigger team). And I enjoy very much what they did about the PvP. The idea is very great. I know alot of people are complaining this game is not like OMD 1 and 2. Well guess what? It is the reason it's not called OMD 1 and 2 lol. And I think it's ok the devs try new things. Bringing back the same game over and over again, this is the real boring and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ things. I prefer devs that try new things. If I wanted to play OMD 1 and 2, I would just go play OMD 1 and 2 lol. I would not play this game. So yeah, I think for a F2P, OMDU is just more than fine and enjoyable. I decided to put some money in it because the devs proved me they were listenning and the game overall is far from being broken and bad. Just try it. You can decide you dont enjoy it. But I dont believe it's a fair reason to give a negative review to say that this game is bad because it's not OMD 1 or 2"... come on lol."

reviewText:
I loved Orcs Must Die 1 and 2. I love the concept. The combination of PFS and TD. And I've been longing to play this game together with more than one friend (as was the fact in OMD2).

But OMD!U is another great gaming concept almost ruined by the Free 2 Play business model.

Fact: The investors and devs must earn their money some way or other.

This requires placing some portion of the game's potential behind a paywall. But this makes the game pretty much like the old days where players paid a fixed fee to unlock the whole game. The investors want max profits. So they turn to the addictive and gullible nature in most of us (and perhaps us gamers in particular). This has caused a surge in games choosing the F2P business model.

For not to be accused of making a Pay 2 Win/Pay 2 Progress-game, there must be a way to attract as many players as possible by offering a grindwall.

By promising LOUD and clear that EVERY aspect of the game is available without having to sink ANY money in the game, the investors try to attract as many players as possible.

As with spam: If only a tiny fraction of the recipients bite, then the conman will strike rich.

To maximize the desire to climb a wall, a large enough portion of the fun must be located on the other side.

If the GRINDwall is too low then players will simply play themselves over it. =Money lost.

For fear of unhappy investors the devs will have to make the grindwall very high. This makes it impossible to climb for casual gamers.
The players who are willing to sink valuable hours of their lives playing a fun-restricted game should get just enough reward - slowly enough - to keep them coming back for more.
But they should also constantly be enticed to pay money to progress faster. The progress must therefore be sufficiently slow. There are many ways to conceal slow pace: long cooldowns, ineficcient traps, puny effects, little game impact,

The promise that the game will eventually become maximum fun should always loom above the next hill.

The grindwall will gradually increase the motivation to defend all the time invested in the game by paying for quicker advancement. In OMD!U it takes the form of chests providing completely random rewards. The more expensive chest you buy the greater the chance for rare loot and greater amounts of it.

This opens up the casino-part of most F2P-games.

Since investors demand a maximization of profits, any player revealing him/herself as willing to play the casino game should be milked as much as possible before they realize they will never get to the greatest enjoyment of the game.
Or they will have to pay a LOT, to reduce the chance of the game being pegged as P2W.

These gamblers must - after all - pay for the players who doesn't pay. Patching, content development, servers and bandwidth costs money.

If the gambling system is designed right the player should believe s/he got something good. But after playing a bit they should realize that it was not that good anyways, and be tempted to protect their earlier investments by gambling some more. Rinse and repeat.

It is human nature to throw more money after lost money, in order to somehow redeem or avoid losing the earlier investments.

If you read this thinking The game is fun as it is": As yourself how much more fun you could have had with a fully unlocked game.
If you read this thinking "I can play myself over the grindwall": Ask yourself how many hours you think you'll have to play to get to the full enjoyment that the game can offer. And if you - perhaps - have gone bored by then. Perhaps you will leave the game having never experienced all the fun it could provide? Perhaps there are other games you could have enjoyed instead? Do you think you will live forever? Time is valuable
date: and we gamers should ask ourselves if gaming companies respect our time or not. They should focus on making games that gives us max amounts of fun
recommended:
and charge a reasonable fee for it. -Rather than having us pay both valuable time and money to never get the full game.

What if you could play every game and enjoy all its potential without having to pay with hours of reduced enjoyment?

When you go to the cinema you can expect to pay a bit in both money and commercials. But after that you get the full movie
hoursPlayed: from start to finish
voteText: in all its glory.\nBut what if they offered a Free 2 Watch business model like F2P:\n- The movie starts great. You love the story
helpfulPercent: and decide to keep watching.\n- But there are loooong scenes of the hero brushing his/her teeth
votesHelpful: eating dinner
votesTotal: reloading weapons
votesFunny: shooting the breeze. It is OK to watch. Not fun
commentsCount: but OK.\n- You will never get to see all the scenes of the movie (or its complete ending). Because when you do you're off the hook and have no incentive to keep wathing.\n- Some of the audience will decide their lives are worth more than their money
column16:
and will start gambling. They will have to pay for all the rest who still take up seats. But will get to skip some of the teeth-brushing and weapon reloading scenes.
- And no one will get to know what the movie wold have been like if it was provided Pay to Watch as the director intended.

Back to the walls:
If a paywall is too low then the game will quickly be pegged as Pay 2 Win. And since this is both a PvP-game as well as PvE-game the devs cannot allow players to purchase themselves to power. If this happens the game will receive crippling reviews and bleed players quickly.

As you can see: The whole F2P concept - by inherent design - ruins games.
Investors could not give a damn about this fact. They are in it to earn money. They do not care about your enjoyment.
The devs are paid by the investors
column17:
and have little say. They are victims of this just as we gamers are.

Why should we accept this?

I implore you: Make a principal decision. Make a statement by supporting the paid games and refusing to play F2P. Let's all contribute to sending the destructive F2P business model to the junkyard of financial history."

reviewText:
Here's a afirst look video 30 mins gameplay, couple of maps: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXRlgUBPMsw

We tried out a couple of the survival game modes, namely the LEVEL:1and LEVEL:2 battlegrounds. The CLIFFSIDE CLASH is the first map you are likely to stumble into which has a castle feel to it, surrounded by water. It felt quite a big map, i think i even got lost at one point.

The UNCHAINED FORTRESS map was available when we hit LEVEL:2 and has a nice feel to it, part building set in a woods or something.

Panic favoured playing the SMOLDER character, mainly as it's any excuse to play a girl! Whist Pain had a go with GABRIELLA and MAXIMILIAN.

Smolder has fire abilities and is a caster, does some great AOE damage, Gabriella is more of a one shot deal with some aoe, whilst Max uses a cross bow to dish the pain.

We discuss what we would like to see improved at the end of the video.

Please also note, we create the SPLIT SCREEN during video editing. I don't think the game has built in split screen.

reviewText:
After 30 hours of playing I went from neutral leaning negative to neutral leaning positive.

Free to Play with Micro Transactions - The content in the shop are wildly expensive and use a token based system as in, you don't even buy the content you buy the gold then you use the gold to buy the content. New Characters (I.E not the default 5 you have access to) are about $10 each, skins are also $10 which is a little ridiculous. You can also buy chests that have rewards inside to speed up the process of crafting traps.

Crafting - In Orcs Must Die 1 and 2 you were awarded skulls based on performance and kills at the end of the level. You would spend those skulls on new traps, items, skins. In Unchained, you'll need a range of different items in exorbitant amounts to craft, upgrade, and tweak traps. SO you'll get the same traps and items that could be enjoyed in OMD1-2, but at a 10x slower rate. On the plus side, you can craft" new heroes instead of paying money to purchase the heroes.

5 player Co-op - I thought this would be a mess of traps but people are usually good about trap placement
recommended: splitting up to stop enemies. You will get the odd person that won't listen or speaks another language
hoursPlayed: but so far it's been rare or not much of an issue. One downside is a cap on the amount of traps that can be placed can be reached very quickly then it becomes an arguing match over what gets cut and what gets a better trap.\n\nNew characters - Fire Mage

reviewText: After a whopping 49 hours of just nothing but grinding in this game, I've managed to acquire 1 thing. The only thing I've been able to buy is a hero who I thought was good and turned out to be horrendous. After making my first terrible choice of champions to make, I decided to then go for a boss minion which only requires 20 summoning lamps. Not so bad right? WRONG. After almost 50 hours, I still only have 17 summoning lamps and not even close to the amount to craft another champion. This game is fun don't get me wrong but the system in which you acquire items is absolutely absurd. I can understand grinding for items but 50 hours for a garbage champion and saving all you can for 1 boss minion is a little bit ridiculous. I'm still going to play this game, however, I would not recommend for anyone who actually wants a life.\n\nUPDATE: I still don't recommend this game, you know why? Because when you finally join a game after waiting 5 minutes in queue and everyone accepts, you immediately have 2 that don't connect and a third teammate who disconnects after the game starts within 2 minutes. There's absolutely no reliable reporting system either without having to go through thier website and upload screenshots of what happened and writing an essay. I've played a countless amount of games in which we have 2-3 teammates who just don't connect and there's nothing you can do except accept the incoming carnage that the other team (who are always all asian and know exactly what to do and when) are about to hand deliver to you on a silver platter. Meanwhile my teammates are raging over the placement of a barricade and a defender is defending a lane that hasn't even opened yet.

reviewText: I've played OMD! 2 for a while, and was pretty hyped for this game to release. I'm underwhelmed.\n\nThe character rotation makes the game a cash mine, as well as grindy to unlock the characters for free. It still feels like an Orcs Must Die! game, but frankly, the characters I was looking forward to, such as the War Mage being a bada** with a blunderbuss, and the sorceress going ham, were gone. They're renamed, nerfed, and the game feels weighted towards the orcs. The traps aren't unique to characters, so one character doesn't have a unique trap to place which does something that can't be duplicated. The weapons and skills change, but they're fairly unoriginal, on the heroes I've looked at. No numbers are also listed on any skills or weapons or most traps, and frankly, I don't know what I'm placing or doing until I take the time out of game to view it, and there it's hard to find. The whole launcher" setup I dislike

reviewText:
The Survival game is quite a lot like the old two games except there are a lot more heroes to choose from.  You very much absolutely can still build trap mazes that take out most of the monsters, though you usually need to have involvement as well.  This is the way the other two games are too so it's not really that different.

I miss having story to play through but this is more about getting in the game quickly with other people.

Free players can pretty much find and craft everything in the game.  People spending a lot of money can definitely have an advantage if you go against them in PvP, but you can build up all you want in Survival and also in Siege co-op before taking others on.  There is nothing spending players can get that free players can't other than some of the skins to change hero looks, it just takes a while for free players to find the crafting ingredients to make all the stuff and to draw Guardians from the free chests.

It's not perfect but it's fun and I'd recommend it for sure.

My biggest complaint would be that some of the heroes' unique abilities are only good in Siege mode and are completely worthless in Survival.  Every unique trap ability can help in Siege, but unfortunately some of the heroes have uniques that are worthless in Survival and it makes it so you don't want to play them in Survival or buy them even though they can be pretty cool otherwise.

Don't let the mixed reviews put you off.  You know how reviews go for Free to Play games.  Free Players get it, find a few little silly things they dislike even if they like the game overall, or get upset when not everything is instantly given to them for free and they down rate the game.

That isn't to say everybody will like it but if you enjoyed either of the first two games I don't really see why you'd have a problem with this one.  It's that same game play only with more modes, more heroes, and unfortunately less story.  And hey it's free, so give it a try either way.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
1.Orcs Must Die Unchained Brings something new too the Orcs Must Die Series. Somehow it brings that MOBA feeling with its new gamemode siege.

4.Every hero has its own use, Midnight is really good at picking hero's off,And thats just one of the many heros.

5.Siege is a mix of PVP and a little of the tower defence aspect, When you are playing defence you must defend against minions and heros ,On offensive you have too push with the minions to get too there rift.

6.The Dev team is amazing they are constantly working on this game, And taking player feed back and even sometimes you can play with the Devs.


Over all its a really fun game and i had tons of fun with my friends and i still am.
Honestly even if you dont like tower defence games you should still pick this up and play.
My Rating 4/5

reviewText:
I'm gonna start off saying that the first two games didn't interest me that much so it's a review comming from someone who's not a fan of the series.

There is a lot of people claiming that it's a moba which isn't entirely true, that is only half of the game. There is also survival and it's tower defense for 5 people.

There is also a lot of people complaining about crafting heroes. Just today an update was released that gives you a lot more rift embers (material required to craft heroes) just by leveling up. And while the craft cost might still be quite high you have to take into account the fact that there is only 12 heroes.

I'm level 12 and I already got enough materials to craft some traps, a trinket I wanted and I have 310/450 rift embers required to craft a hero. I would probably have enough to craft a hero if I didn't only play as one character. You level up faster by playing different heroes.

If you have friends to play with then you should try it out because it's fun.

reviewText:
First of all this game is not meant to be exactly like Orcs Must Die 1 or 2! It is OMD's spin on a MOBA! Too many reviews complaining about how different this game is than the first two...

My ONLY complaint was that they had such a low player base and since it's mainly PvP I stopped playing it for a while as I couldn't find people to play against. I felt like they barely advertised and most gamers I talked too had no clue this game was out or in open beta... I am extremely happy it is finally released on Steam and I hope that this will greatly increase the player base!

reviewText:
Pros:
-Fun game when you're on a decent team
-Queue wait is relatively short

Cons:
-It's super tedious unlocking new heroes and traps (at 30 hours I've unlocked one character and 2 traps and upgraded one trap)
-You can't choose the map/level you'd like to play with random people.
-In survival's matchmaker mode, people tend to leave games after they've seen the level/map leaving you with a 3 man team and making it near impossible to win in higher levels.

Overall, I enjoy the game, and it will probably get better when other character's and traps become unclocked. Hopefully the devs will make drops more common or change the unlocking requirements soon.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
More heroes and new game mechanics are a fun add-on to the game series, so kudos for that.

However, I'm just not interested in playing a MOBA-esque OMD with a bunch of strangers. If that's not your cup of tea and you'd like to play the game with your friends (or alone), it currently dissolves into an attrocious grindfest. Yeah... how fun do you think it is to play through the same map over, and over, and over again just so you can get a single trap or level up so not to be overwhelmed in the next map? Top it off with the standard keep coming back every day for free rewards" F2P gimmick to make the whole thing feel extra sleazy.

Really liked the first two games. This one can certainly be fun at times

reviewText:
Similar to Dungeon Defenders - but more enjoyable.

The focus is more on traps than on character. You can unlock new traps or upgrade your current traps with what seems like a massive grind. This is presumably designed to help with replay longevity. It does make it very satisfying when you unlock something new because of how difficult it is to unlock anything at all.

Focus is not on your hero/character. You do not increase dmg/health/etc the more you play. Those stats reset each map and are only minimally increased within the map.

I very much enjoy it. My only gripe is that of the 5 players in each map without fail at least 1 of them disconnects and there isn't a great system in place to compensate for this.

reviewText:
as of Todays patch 4/6/2016 crafting characters to use in game are even CHEAPER than before. Which they were already easy to get but now even easier. Many of the whiners have been answered but now i better not hear any complaining about heroes :P.


Time for a honest and thoughtful review of the game with in depth experience. So many people who leave negative reviews simply haven't even made it past the starting maps and are complaining about loot and earning new players when they haven't even gotten into the game yet or the other side is the self entitled people who think when they play a game for a couple hours to a week they should be given everything in it for free or it sucks. They barely scraped the surface with their 3 hours of game time. I am level 90 in game currently i was the first to hit the leaderboards! Let me tell you a little bit about the game and what it really holds for those looking to get in on the action! I have never felt the need to write a review for a game ever until this game.

Lets start with Leveling,Gearing, Traps, loot and unlocking characters.

-Leveling- In OMDU you have a handful of free characters to use every week or biweekly. During that time you join into some wild siege (pvp) or Hold out and make some Orc heads Roll in Survival with your friends. You use whatever character you select and fight it out, the end of the match if you win Gives you greater rewards than if you lose, but even if you lose... you get rewards! So as you level up your characters, it levels up something called account level". this is your total level. The Higher this is the stronger all your characters are on any of the survival maps and you are much closer to unlocked some different skins.

-Gear- You can craft from a handful of different pieces of gear that you can use to buff
recommended: heal or manipulate things around you during the game. You can equip 2 types of gear at one time and use them in your matches. It's very simple and easy to use! You have quite a few choices right now with so many more to come!\n\n-Traps- Lets talk about traps in the game. There are so many mix and matches you can do with traps it is unreal! The combinations could almost be endless and with new traps coming eventually it is only going to expand your aresenal for maiming and crushing your enemies! You can earn Free traps from chest that you loot from in game or simply farm the materials from different pvp or survival modes and craft the trap you are looking to make! One of the complaints you see some people make is "im no getting enough loot
hoursPlayed: or skulls! this game has a paywall!" I will tell you right now as being one of the highest players in the game with many items and progressing as fast as i am
voteText: there is no paywall. There is only those who understand how to have fun and enjoy the Defence type of game and farm your materials or just sit around complaining. All the materials you need can easily be earned by playing different maps in the game. i have some of the highest tier traps in game completely free from farming and chest earned in game. There is no paywall that is for sure! find a team and wreck a map
helpfulPercent: or do what others do and sit in general chat complaining at level 11 that they dont have it all handed to them.\n\n-Loot- As somewhat mentioned above. lets get into loot. Loot is earned through pvp and survival game modes. You can kill minions and they will drop all kinds of loot
votesHelpful: some maps have a specific common loot type on it
votesTotal: but depending on the RNG you coul get any rare on just about any map or any uncommon. Some maps spawn specfic minions that have a greater chance of getting the material you need. It is such a simple loot system that is actually pretty generous and rewarding to those who finish their matches and don't quit mid game
votesFunny:
now as mentioned above. even if you lose! you still get to keep any loot farmed and have a chance at earning a chest! You are well taken care of in game for a f2p game.

-Characters- Last but not least are characters. so so many new people complain right off the bat about characters not being given to them for free and having to play with roation characters. Lets break this down to the Pros of using rotation characters while you farm materials to CRAFT a character for you to OWN perm.

-Pros- You get to use new characters each week/bi week. During the use of those new characters you get to level them up individually adding to your account level thus making you stronger and getting to test/enjoy new characters and find which ones you might like to craft once you gain the materials to craft them. ALL the characters use the same ammount and same type of materials to craft one. SO you dont have to worry about one you like being ten times harder to get than another because they are all the same price material wise. You can even earn free characters and skins from in game chest which you have a chance of getting at the end of every match! If you Craft and own a character you gain a small bonus for exp gain for that character and they are no longer locked in with weekly rotations. The material you will see people complaining about in negative reviews are EMBERS. These items are very very easy to farm. You could craft your first character in 1-2 weeks of playing the game while relaxing with your friends. These embers can be earned every day in a daily. They can be earned in quest
commentsCount: chest in game or Loot drops from in game minions.\n\nAll in All i have to share that i believe they did a wonderful Job so far with this F2P style game. There is NO paywall! This game truly is one of the best F2P i have ever played yet and there is so much more content coming along with the Devs always working rapidly fixing bugs

reviewText:
Fun!
Free!!!
Hilarious
Easy
Challenging
Strategic
Progression
Choices
Addictive

These are just some of the words I would use to explain this game. IT also has everything I need for my hardcore PvP side. Siege is very competitive and fast to get games in. It is one of the more interesting MOBA’s out there now. I would not even call it a MOBA. Maybe a Tower Defense MOBA?

Survival mode is perfect. You can play by yourself or with up to 4 other players. It is easy to get started and learn but it gets challenging very fast as you go through the levels.

I am not sure what people are saying about P2W? It is as free as you want it to be and none of the power progression stuff transfer to the PvP game. Anything that gains you power in PvP is available from the start and can be crafted for free if you work towards it.

I would give this game 9/10 and as the content increases I would imagine most people would rate it 10/10. Check it out and find the part of the game that is just right for you.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: I don't really write reviews, so this will probably be my first and only review. Just wanted to get the community ambassador badge so you probably shouldn't pay attention to this if you want a review from someones experienced in these.

Positives:
- Fun gameplay
- Nice art style
- Not pay to win
- Interesting characters and abilities
- Funny things occasionally said by the characters
- Fun with friends because it causes you to lose your ♥♥♥♥ trying to defend

Negatives:
- People tend to leave if you have the slightest chance of losing, thereby guaranteeing you lose
- Hordes of enemies can become a little overwhelming at times (maybe I'm just bad at the game, idk.)
- Only the matches themselves are in fullscreen. Rest of game is stuck in windowed mode with no way to put it in fullscreen. (Just a personal annoyance for me.)
- When in fullscreen, you can't press the windows key to tab out. You're completely stuck unless you ctrl+alt+delete and start task manager. (Again, just a personal annoyance.)

Conclusion: Probably great if you love MOBAS. I'm not personally a fan of them but I still found it kind of fun. Probably won't play much more though.

reviewText:
I find it rather odd that this game has a mixed rating.  Allow me to change that with this review.

To begin with, I saw Markiplier playing this game, and seeing it was a free game, I thought to give it a try.  What I experienced is a MOBA that innovates the formula in a different way by combining tower defense strategy with it.  I enjoyed building my own trap schemes to kill enemy minions and being able to choose my own minions to send to battle rather than the staple soldiers that just charge forward and attack the first thing they see.

There are currently two modes: Survival and Siege.  Survival is a 5 player Co-op to defend your rift rom enemy waves and after an x number of waves, another portal will open allowing minions to charge from that portal and thus needing to split the team to make up for a lack of defense at that segment.  Siege is a 10 player PvP that acts similarly to Survival, but the key difference is that there is an opposing team of players trying to take out your rift while you do the same to theirs.

Minions are a wide variety of high defense, long range, and quick Get-From-Point-A-To-Point-B mindset.  Choosing which minions get sent out can change the attack strategy quite a bit whether you want a bulwark team of bears, ogres or giants that can take on any hero, trap or guardian or a speedy team of satyrs and kobolds that can take down enemy gates faster so they can reach the opposing team's rift portal.

Traps themselves are also quite effective and the fact that some heroes have their own unique trap or glyph adds more personality to the game.  One gripe I do have for traps is that some can be godawful expensive and being that you want to be able to add to the trap scheme as quickly as possible, it can be a setback to wait for enough coins for a better trap, but it's just the case of compromise whether to put something down now or save up for it later.

Finally the heroes, while not at SMITE or LOL levels of variety (yet), offer a unique hero for any occasion.  I find myself liking Stinkeye and Blackpaw the most, the former with his intricate ability to use totems to give him a edge in any situation and the latter for his ability to move quickly on the map and quickly wittle down any enemy's health.

Overall, it's a very fun game and a very fun MOBA, if that's your thing.  If you want a change from the typical 3 lanes, 3 towers in each lane, rehashed schematic, give OMCU a try.

reviewText: I do not really know why the p2w hate. It is a F2P game though, so progession and items are acquired through playing, in a matter very comparable to League of Legends.\nThe PvE could be seperated a little more from the PvP to allow for some new funky combos, but its still a lot of fun none the less.\nThe PvP is soo much gun though, it is unique from the more popular MOBA's of our time i.e. LoL, DoTA and HoTS. Once again not pay to win, just unlocking progression as you play no different than unlocking guns in CoD 4 or Champs in League. If you like competitive team games, OMD Unchained is definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of OMD 1 and 2, which was an action tower defense game.

This is NOT Orcs Must Die. This is an extremely crippled OMD2 (Survival mode) attached to a poorly-designed MOBA (Siege mode) that clearly lifts its UI and character inspiration from LoL and DotA, directly, and both modes suffer for it, tremendously.

I cannot recommend this game in its current form.

It is designed with the worst freemium structure found in most mobile games.

This game is short. You'll have explored every map in the game in less than 2 hours of play.

The game is extremely restrictive. It stops just short of playing the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed game for you. There are tight restrictions on where and how you can place traps. The game tells you where your killzones are going to be. They tell you how many and where your guardians are going to be. They tell you how many of each trap, spell, trinket and consumable you're allowed to bring, instead of letting you mix it up, yourself.

This game has no solo play. It is balanced exclusively as a team game. As a team game, it's good.

Character progression is deliberately designed to be a nuisance. The process of unlocking traps with skulls has been replaced with an elaborate crafting system, which means the process of playing for hours to unlock everything has been replaced with playing for ACTUAL DAYS. It takes, I would hazard, about 24 times as long as previous entries - probably much longer - to unlock all the content in this game.

The game is trying to balance for two modes at once, and it fails both modes. You have to play both modes, whether you want to, or not, because some crafting ingredients are essentially impossible to get outside of specific modes because of an insane imbalance in drop rates. And if you do play both modes, know that the upgrades you apply to a trap for use in one mode are often not available or useful in the other. The same with champion abilities; your characters level up during each game, but there are lots of abilities that are clearly intended for one mode and garbage in the other.

So you spend a week of casual play and you're ready to craft a trap. You are terrified. Why?

Traps are now a colossal investment, which you cannot experiment with, so you blindly commit hours of grinding to a choice which you cannot reverse and will very likely regret, especially if traps prove to be highly imbalanced (which they might very well be, but so few people have all the damned traps that there's no way there's enough real-world testing and community feedback to know, for sure).

The publisher is ♥♥♥♥. On the forums, there are actual threads with these desperate goons begging us to tell them how they can make money off of this.

Make Orcs Must Die. Let us pay for it. Let us decide how to play with what we're given. Let us experiment. This is a small piece of an Orcs Must Die game. It's designed to frustrate, and it's lacking in content and depth, so even if I got past the frustration, there'd be no ♥♥♥♥ing reward, anyway.

reviewText:
My first impression was, what is the diffrence between this and the old Orcs Must die games? Well, after playing the survival mode for a couple of games, I headed to the siege mode. What is the siege mode?

The siege mode is like smite combined with the older classical versions of Orcs Must Die. It's 5v5 and is one of the most immersive and fun games I've tried in a while. The game style is MOBA, with a slight RTS feel, due to the fact that you can control which minions you wanna spawn etc.

That being said, this is not your standard MOBA like game, you can choose to have the defence trait or the attacker trait in the hero select screen. These will give your a certain trait to help you do either, as the name implies. As far as I've observed there is a defence and an attack lane, personally I've only really played defence, since I love placing traps and making fun little routes for the minions to die in, I like building stuff.

The obejctive is as in most MOBA games, to reach the enemy spawn point and take it down. Reffering to League of Legends nexus and Dotas whatever (I have never really tried Dota, so I don't know what it's called). The game itself is third person.

All around a fantastic game, that just recently really opened to the public. I look forward to what this game is gonna offer. Right now as it is, I am completly in love with this game.

reviewText:
Product received for free

TLDR; If you like coop tower defence games with a bit of action, this is game your game. It's like Orcs Must Die (OMD) 1 and 2, only online. the PvP game can be skipped if you like the PvE gameplay from OMD 1 and 2. I recommend the game. The game has a few issues with are mainly the grinding which can be boring.

What is Orcs Must die Unchained (OMDU)?For those who haven’t played OMD 1 and 2 here’s a short description. It’s an action packed tower defence game where you build traps to defend against orcs. The gameplay is seen in third person where you control a hero. During the game you can shoot and use abilities. The game consists of two game types. PvP that’s kinda plays like a moba (only with OMD twist). In the PvP you build traps and lead armies to the enemies rift. There’s also a PvE coop part where you defend against a certain amount (or after level 80 endless) of waves. Each wave is more difficult than the other. You have to stop getting the orcs to your rift. Your rift only has a certain amount of health.

ProsFree to play
Why not just give the game a try? It's free! While the game has micro transaction it can be completely forgetting. Only things you have to pay for are the skins. The rest you can farm.

The game has good humour like OMD 1 and 2 has
Often the Orcs are heroes will shout some stuff which are pretty funny one-liners. The orcs also sometimes die in the most funny ways. For example eye pop out when walking past fire.

graphics are cartoony and fit the tone
While the graphics aren't something that will make your PC cry and ooze high graphic quality, the graphics look good enough. Coming from OMD 1 and 2 this is a step-up. The graphics look cartoony and fit with the tone of the game. The game isn't even high demanding in terms of hardware requirements.

Frequent updates to fix the game and add new content
Almost every week we get a patch that fixes stuff. Almost every month we get new content.

Levelling your account doesn't take too long
As of writing I played 46 hours so far and I'm level 55. Levelling up happens by levelling your heroes. Each level of your hero gets added up to your account. So if you have played with two heroes that are level 2, you are level 4. If you own a hero you get more XP which levels you up faster. With each level you get, you get rewards in terms of unlocks and loot.

Load times aren't bad
I load a game within 20-30 seconds I would say. In-game you need to wait for other players though.

Heroes are varied
Each hero brings their own power, traps and gamestyle. There are even heroes that excel at solo-damage, trap building, magic, tanking, etc. There's a hero for each type of player. Each hero can be build each match up to 6 talents maxing at level 12 where you pick your last talent. Each week a new rotation is done to play a hero for free (but get less XP if you don't own the hero).

Varied maps
Each map brings it's own atmosphere, challenges and recommended traps. No map feels the same in terms of tactics. Some maps even give fun things like one map has swimming sharks. Once an orc dies the shark eat the orcs. Over time you revisit a map only this time the challenge goes up by having bigger, badder and more waves.

Traps
The traps are the main thing about this game. It's fun to place traps and make various combinations. Just like OMD 1 and 2 you can place traps on ceilings, walls and ground. Each trap has it's own use and price. Some traps are better than other. You can upgrade traps to your liking and even customize them a little. Customizing comes in term of catering to your playstyle. For example you use a lot of fire traps? Then gives traps a damage boost when an Orc is on fire!

Unchained
The main addition of the game is that combos gives unchained. Unchained gives the hero HP, mana, cooldown and damage boosts. It's fun to go unchained and see combos fly around.

PvP
The PvP mode is a nice optional addition and gives a fun twist to the moba market. You lead armies and help your armie avoid traps and heroes. You can also build traps to help you defend your rift. I myself hardly play it because I find the PvE mode more fun. But the PvP mode is fun.

Cons
Farm a lot
As many have stated the farming for items just is too much at the moment. You farm items by picking them up, levelling up, getting chest (you get them from time or you buy them), completing quests or completing daily quests. So while you do get enough chance to get items, it's just not enough. The item cost to get traps or upgrade them is just too much at the moment. I need to play like 10-15 games orso to get something. OMD 1 and 2 was accessible in terms of upgrades. Not to mention my bigger gripe with the game is that you yourself have to pick up items in-game. This can't be done because often you'll defend a lane. Items despawn after a round which doesn't make it easier. They do really need to make items pickup group based so everyone gets it. I feel that the farming of the items in this game is the biggest con and needs to fixed for this game to grow.

Queueing is long and weird
at the moment it's just screwed. Sometimes the game matches me with 2 other people for a map that is not balanced for 3 people (but balanced for 5 people). We always lose when this happens. Queuing also takes too long at times.

Enemies destroying barricades
At the moment there are enemies in the game that destroy barricades. Barricades are needed to make a maze so that the Orcs walk a longer path. Some enemies however destroy the barricades within a few seconds. People in end-game have a hard time dealing with this. Heck the most of the game is figuring out an ideal path by placing traps and barricades.

Trap limit too low sometimes
Often people are struggling because the trap limit is too low. Most maps give you 120 traps to the max. This limit is easy to reach in the later levels. I would say 150 trap limit would be better and balances the game more.

reviewText:
While playing my first PVP match, me and my friend realized a few things. Since this is currently in beta, if you see your team losing, there is absolutely zero reason to stay in a losing pvp match. Furthermore this game will almost certainly never be popular, so even when it is released people will just leave. Now you might argue that this is an issue with any online game, and I would agree, but for a less popular multiplayer game with only five players on your team, constant leavers will just grind on your soul until you give up on the game.

The PVE, as you may expect, was fine, although playing with random people will be an excruciating experience. I HEAVILY reccommend playing with friends over voice chat, as other random people will constantly walk into your lane and build in awful positions, ruining paths and mazes.


This game should obviously only be played for the PvE. If you do so, the maze/wall mechanics feel like a nice balance between the heavy mazing of Sanctum, and the very simple walling off of lanes from dungeon defenders. It did not appeal to me, but this may be enoyable for you.

+PVE with up to four friends is the same fun, hectic experience.
+More heroes to play gives more variation.

-I do not foresee any future for PVP besides groups queueing up together to smash uncoordinated groups. It may be fun when these groups clash, but otherwise I believe the random people will slowly just DC from the game and leave one by one (this was the case in the games I played that it looked like we may lose).
-Admittedly I did not play for an extended period of time, but the Crafting system where you pick up materials from fallen NPCs to unlock/upgrade your traps looks like it may take a long time.
-If you gain 65 Hero crafting materials from dailies, and 25 from leveling, from dailies alone the process for a new hero (450) would require about 7 days of playing dailies. However, in my specific case, two of the dailies required playing 10 games on two different champions. After about 8-10 games I was getting bored for the day, since the base gameply is fairly repetitive. This means for semi-casual players, the grind to unlock your favorite champion you experience on free week rotation may be an arduous process.

Someone once said (I believe it was TotalBiscuit) that once a game starts charging money, such as microtransactions, the game should be considered as released. Seeing as the developers have no qualms about charging in the in-game store,  I will consider the main mechanics of their game complete, with allowances for connectivity issues. I'm kind of a first impressions person, and can determine in the first 30 minutes or so if I will enjoy the game. I preferred dungeon defenders over this game for a multiplayer TD experience.
