reviewText:
I like the game! It's OrksMustDie in a nutshell and I would love to give it the thumbs up!
Problem I have with it is the grind... Now I understand it's free to play so they have to do something to make money and extend the game life for the player. This is done by the fact it will probably take you 50+ hours to upgrade one trap.... One! And that's just to get it too lvl 2. I can't imagine how long it would take after that to upgrade it again... Your getting the picture here right? 100s of hours you would need to soak into this game just to upgrade a few traps so you can progress. Of course you can spend money to get resources if you wan't to... Dont do that!

That wouldn't be a bad thing, but the problem is you will get stuck on the same levels over and over again farming resources because you traps are not strong enough to kill the mobs in the higher levels. This makes the game repetitive and extremely boring as you use the same tactic to beat the same level over and over and over and over... It doesn't hold your attention. I have only 10hours in this game at the moment of writing this and the thought of going back to that grind makes me shudder...

Please lower the cost of upgrading traps... Would make the game so much better! I would considering going back to it if you did :P But for now I can't recommend it unless you really really enjoy grind games. I mean it's free so go try it for yourself!

reviewText: This game has potential to be really good, it has the humor and design of its predecessors and seems to be taking more of a moba twist to keep up with the current trend of competitive gaming. Unfortunately, I find that the gameplay itself to be lacking in excitement, the hallways of traps you create with friends or allies don't seem to nearly be as fun as they used to be, and I am left feeling like playing it just for the chore of grinding resourses that drop in the levels.\n\nThere are unlockable characters, traps, loot, etc, which can be purchased if you don't have the patiece for it, but you can also earn the upgrades and stuff through plaing the game like any other moba title. It isn't pay to win like some reviewers might say. I really hope they add more heroes and traps and somehow improve the level of excitement of the gameplay.

reviewText:
Not a continuation of the great seriesAt the current point in time I do not recommend this game for varios reasons.

A) The game involves extreme grinding. There are a dozen crafting materials and getting traps requires a significant amount of grinding. Unlike the previous games, one can not simply pick a trap one likes and upgrade it over time to maximize its performance. One has to farm the particular crafting items over and over again using the same 5 simple and annoying traps to finally be able to craft this trap in the first place.

B) There is little variation in the players' loadout because it takes ages to unlock a single new trap. Whereas it was possible to reset the loadout in previous games it is not possible any longer. Thus, one has to spend additional time in the game doing the exact same thing with the exact same traps to achieve a marginal level of trap variation.

C) The free-to-play business model is frustrating. I'd rather pay money for the game to have an even battlefield in multiplayer. Currently people paying for the game have a significant advantage as they can skip a significant part of the grinding process and easily destroy people who spend an equal amount of time on the game simply because they were able to afford better items at lower levels (e.g. items granting brief invincibility).

All-in-all, while Robot did a lot of work to improve the game and to re-invent parts of it by adding a MOBA style multiplayer mode - I feel that there is little appeal to OMD players. The game feels like it is designed for a new customer group such as SMITE players and did not fulfill my expectations.

reviewText:
First, people complaining about P2W.

Not P2W, pay to skip. The difference is everything is obtainable for free. People who pay will MAYBE stomp in a few matches, have their MMR go up, then play against people who have put a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of hours into the game. Suddenly massive skill difference. The character buffs from items that buff you up are pretty much all <13% increases to your stats and almost all of those buffs are conditional like + damage to a specific type of enemy, + whatever ♥♥♥♥ing stat when you're standing next to some specific thing. I've played for about 5 hours, I've crafted two traps and two items to use and am half way towards getting one of the expensive heroes. Noticeable progression in this is a lot faster than majority of F2P games, and even some games you have to buy and pay a ♥♥♥♥ing subscription to.

Now actual gameplay and mechanics.

Biggest differences I noticed were graphics, how good the controls are, and that there's no ♥♥♥♥ing wind belt. The way you move your character in the first and second games always felt a little awkward to me, I'm not sure exactly what they changed about it but it's a hell of a lot better in this. The co-op part of the game, survival, is basically the same as before. You gain level up and choose buffs in every match like MOBAs do. The unlockable weapons have been turned different heroes and active abilities which I like a bit more. Most of the old traps are still in this, there are a couple new ones and they can still be upgraded though I'm not sure exactly how to do it. Combat is nice, you're a lot weaker but larger team and stronger traps makes up for it. In co-op occasionally an enemy hero will spawn and they're actually pretty dangerous 1v1. Flying guys aren't in this but there are a few new enemy types to make up for it, my favorite ones are the bears that carry shields cause they're ♥♥♥♥ing bears with shields.

PVP! I love how they did roles. Instead of having all the characters forced into specific roles, you pick whatever you want to play and set your role, which will give you a buff to whatever that role is supposed to do. There are still good reasons to pick certain ones over others but it seems to mostly apply to people that want to defend. So far I haven't seen a character that can't be played offensively very well. There also seems to be a bit more team work needed than MOBAs. This has all the basic things that MOBAs have like the lanes, item and character builds, neutral enemies, and ganking but there's also having to spawn your own minions, switching them to counter, and resource farming to upgrade them. The traditional tower thingies have been replaced by guardians. They function pretty much the same but fits the theme better. Combat between players is pretty satisfying, if you liked playing S/MNC, or Smite, then you'll probably like the PVP in this.

Also I don't feel like making a proper conclusion, If you really liked the first two games, don't dismiss this just because some people hate Gameforge. Give it a chance and maybe get addicted.

reviewText: orcs must die unchained is a f2p orcs must die sequel with 3 game modes: practice,survival and siege. survival is stanadrd orcs must die with 5 other players. Siege is a 5v5 moba-like compitition to get 20 less of your minions into the enemy rift while protecting your rift from enemy minions. when map specific requirements are met a boss minion can be sommuned by the enemy or by your team and they are much more powerful than typical minions. now onto the most hated thing on this game: the crafting. it's not that bad. you earn materials by playing games and then use the materials to craft traps,minions,bosses and guardians. item gathering IS NOT GRINDY it's just butthurt fans ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about the changes to stuff gathering. The game also includes 12 diverse heroes with 2 special abilities and a primary and secondary attack and every 3 levels up to level 12 you can buff your hero out if 3 options but you can only pick 1 of the 3 options and some work better in the different game modes.\n\noverall the game is very fun free to play and i haven't spent a penny on the microtransactions or anything else in the game give the game a download and see for yourself!

reviewText:
Pro:

* Enemies flying through the air and/or exploding.
* Visuals, Sounds, Humor.
* /Dance /Taunt
* Hotkey voice commands.
* No obvious pay to win mechanics.
* Everything besides skins can be unlocked through a crafting system.
* Hero playstyles are mostly each unique.
* Loadout customization allows for a lot of variation.
* Survival is a fully multiplayer version of Orcs Must Die.
* Siege is a fun hybrid gamemode of OMD and MOBA reminicent of Monday Night Combat.


Con:

* Each hero is limited to one weapon unlike OMD2
* Hero Traits need some balancing and tweaking so all of them are viable choices.
* Not many different maps for siege mode.

reviewText:
This -is- a very interesting and enjoyable game.
Sadly, it currently relies too much on pay to win.

Hopefully, in the future, they'll reduce the amount of p2w for this game, and make it more appealing to those who wish to just have a fun experience.

Definetly give the game a try.

[Edit]

This game actually doesn't have that big of a paywall.
After playing for a while, I realized that you can pay  to get a chance at some good loot items, but for the most part, f2p users and p2w users are on a same level.

The game does a great job at balancing players and putting them into lobby's with users who are close to each other in items, or should be close.

To those looking for a new take on moba's, try this out, and for those who want a DD2, or OMD change of pace/challenge, give this game a try!

reviewText:
It is the first time I am leaving a game review, so bare with me.

Here is what it comes down to: I honestly think people are being unfair in their reviews.

For a F2P game, I think it is pretty god damn good. Sure, you will not immediatly have access to as many tools and options as you did in previous games of the franchise, but that is to be expected with this model. And crafting in NOT that complicated if you have half of a functioning brain.

In addition,I have NOT have ANY experience making me think that this game is working on a pay to win model, and that's accounting experience in both PVE and PVP.

I have tried so many F2P games on steam, and never been hooked as much as I have with this game. You can hop on a off mutiple times a day, complete your daily quest, and just leave it for a couple day and come back. Matchmaking is a work of art, I never have to wait more than 20 seconds for a game. The community (so far) is welcoming, chatty and helpful.

IMO, this is the best F2P game of 2016 so far... please try it and don't let negative reviews drive you away.

Siege is a 5v5 moba-like compitition to get 20 less of your minions into the enemy rift while protecting your rift from enemy minions. when map specific requirements are met a boss minion can be sommuned by the enemy or by your team and they are much more powerful than typical minions. now onto the most hated thing on this game: the crafting. it's not that bad. you earn materials by playing games and then use the materials to craft traps,minions,bosses and guardians. item gathering IS NOT GRINDY it's just butthurt fans ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about the changes to stuff gathering. The game also includes 12 diverse heroes with 2 special abilities and a primary and secondary attack and every 3 levels up to level 12 you can buff your hero out if 3 options but you can only pick 1 of the 3 options and some work better in the different game modes.\n\noverall the game is very fun free to play and i haven't spent a penny on the microtransactions or anything else in the game give the game a download and see for yourself!

reviewText:
It is the first time I am leaving a game review, so bare with me.

Here is what it comes down to: I honestly think people are being unfair in their reviews.

For a F2P game, I think it is pretty god damn good. Sure, you will not immediatly have access to as many tools and options as you did in previous games of the franchise, but that is to be expected with this model. And crafting in NOT that complicated if you have half of a functioning brain.

In addition,I have NOT have ANY experience making me think that this game is working on a pay to win model, and that's accounting experience in both PVE and PVP.

I have tried so many F2P games on steam, and never been hooked as much as I have with this game. You can hop on a off mutiple times a day, complete your daily quest, and just leave it for a couple day and come back. Matchmaking is a work of art, I never have to wait more than 20 seconds for a game. The community (so far) is welcoming, chatty and helpful.

IMO, this is the best F2P game of 2016 so far... please try it and don't let negative reviews drive you away.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
OMD Unchained is great, it feels great and it's free, without gating stuff behind a pay wall.

So far I have had tons of laughs, a lot of fun and gameplay possible to adjust depending on your skill level. Is the game too easy? No problem, you can jump into level 12 as level 6 if you feel like you're up for the challenge.

The in-game crafting system and rewards are confusing at first, however they are handed out rapidly, so I've gotten enough rewards to progress and craft new items every 30-45min of gametime, which is about 3 games played.

As most other F2P games, such as League of Legends, Heroes of the Storm, Smite and to a lesser extent Hearthstone, you can speed up your progress through the shop. So far though, I really haven't felt like I had to. Even skins can be unlocked through crafting so progress does indeed seem a lot faster in OMD compared to Hearthstone, Heroes of the Storm and League of Legends.

The few issues I have with the game, is the UI looks awful and it's not the best. Especially the crafting and inventory system could use a good makeover to make it a bit more convenient and obvious. I like the huge amoun of funny crafting items and recipes, but better descriptions and a better overview would be great.

The characters are fun, diverse to play - but what the hell happened to Maximillian? He turned from being an Arrogant, unknowing, ignorant and kind of a stupid person into 100% Obnoxious. It's kind of sad, I thought he was great in the previous games, but for some reasons, he's just really obnouxious to listen to in OMD U. However, a lot of the other chars are there, whenever I need a break from his handsome jawline and crazy comments.

The Siege tutorial is garbage though, it is as if it's a very impatient YouTuber who's commenting it, so I also hope it gets abit of a makeover before the release.

Overall, I'd say get it! Ignore the shop, you honestly don't need it, even if you only play casual. Find some friends and jump into high levels and see if you can do them together - it's great fun!

reviewText:
After reviewed most popular reviews and played it myself for 5 hrs.
The game itself: In the essence it is an Tower defense with MOBA element put into a FPS game style.

if you want to understand the full depth of the game, you might find yourself into deep trouble as the upgrade system is mathmatically impossible for casual players play few hours a week to accomplish. (as so far, 5 hrs of game play gathered less than 1% of special materials needed for upgrade any entry level game traps)

The fun: you get smash orcs in few different ways if you play single player. When you paly with multi-player mode, you will find your strategy is useless that people just randomly use up all the spaces. But still you can enjoy an hour or two of game element without feeling too repetitive.

The take home message is this is a hardcore game under a softcore skin. It is fun for a few hours but if you want to become any sort of pro or do well in MOBA element, you better prepare thousands of hours and some $$ ahead

reviewText:
While playing my first PVP match, me and my friend realized a few things. Since this is currently in beta, if you see your team losing, there is absolutely zero reason to stay in a losing pvp match. Furthermore this game will almost certainly never be popular, so even when it is released people will just leave. Now you might argue that this is an issue with any online game, and I would agree, but for a less popular multiplayer game with only five players on your team, constant leavers will just grind on your soul until you give up on the game.

The PVE, as you may expect, was fine, although playing with random people will be an excruciating experience. I HEAVILY reccommend playing with friends over voice chat, as other random people will constantly walk into your lane and build in awful positions, ruining paths and mazes.


This game should obviously only be played for the PvE. If you do so, the maze/wall mechanics feel like a nice balance between the heavy mazing of Sanctum, and the very simple walling off of lanes from dungeon defenders. It did not appeal to me, but this may be enoyable for you.

+PVE with up to four friends is the same fun, hectic experience.
+More heroes to play gives more variation.

-I do not foresee any future for PVP besides groups queueing up together to smash uncoordinated groups. It may be fun when these groups clash, but otherwise I believe the random people will slowly just DC from the game and leave one by one (this was the case in the games I played that it looked like we may lose).
-Admittedly I did not play for an extended period of time, but the Crafting system where you pick up materials from fallen NPCs to unlock/upgrade your traps looks like it may take a long time.
-If you gain 65 Hero crafting materials from dailies, and 25 from leveling, from dailies alone the process for a new hero (450) would require about 7 days of playing dailies. However, in my specific case, two of the dailies required playing 10 games on two different champions. After about 8-10 games I was getting bored for the day, since the base gameply is fairly repetitive. This means for semi-casual players, the grind to unlock your favorite champion you experience on free week rotation may be an arduous process.

Someone once said (I believe it was TotalBiscuit) that once a game starts charging money, such as microtransactions, the game should be considered as released. Seeing as the developers have no qualms about charging in the in-game store,  I will consider the main mechanics of their game complete, with allowances for connectivity issues. I'm kind of a first impressions person, and can determine in the first 30 minutes or so if I will enjoy the game. I preferred dungeon defenders over this game for a multiplayer TD experience.

reviewText:
Product received for free

TLDR; If you like coop tower defence games with a bit of action, this is game your game. It's like Orcs Must Die (OMD) 1 and 2, only online. the PvP game can be skipped if you like the PvE gameplay from OMD 1 and 2. I recommend the game. The game has a few issues with are mainly the grinding which can be boring.

What is Orcs Must die Unchained (OMDU)?For those who haven’t played OMD 1 and 2 here’s a short description. It’s an action packed tower defence game where you build traps to defend against orcs. The gameplay is seen in third person where you control a hero. During the game you can shoot and use abilities. The game consists of two game types. PvP that’s kinda plays like a moba (only with OMD twist). In the PvP you build traps and lead armies to the enemies rift. There’s also a PvE coop part where you defend against a certain amount (or after level 80 endless) of waves. Each wave is more difficult than the other. You have to stop getting the orcs to your rift. Your rift only has a certain amount of health.

ProsFree to play
Why not just give the game a try? It's free! While the game has micro transaction it can be completely forgetting. Only things you have to pay for are the skins. The rest you can farm.

The game has good humour like OMD 1 and 2 has
Often the Orcs are heroes will shout some stuff which are pretty funny one-liners. The orcs also sometimes die in the most funny ways. For example eye pop out when walking past fire.

graphics are cartoony and fit the tone
While the graphics aren't something that will make your PC cry and ooze high graphic quality, the graphics look good enough. Coming from OMD 1 and 2 this is a step-up. The graphics look cartoony and fit with the tone of the game. The game isn't even high demanding in terms of hardware requirements.

Frequent updates to fix the game and add new content
Almost every week we get a patch that fixes stuff. Almost every month we get new content.

Levelling your account doesn't take too long
As of writing I played 46 hours so far and I'm level 55. Levelling up happens by levelling your heroes. Each level of your hero gets added up to your account. So if you have played with two heroes that are level 2, you are level 4. If you own a hero you get more XP which levels you up faster. With each level you get, you get rewards in terms of unlocks and loot.

Load times aren't bad
I load a game within 20-30 seconds I would say. In-game you need to wait for other players though.

Heroes are varied
Each hero brings their own power, traps and gamestyle. There are even heroes that excel at solo-damage, trap building, magic, tanking, etc. There's a hero for each type of player. Each hero can be build each match up to 6 talents maxing at level 12 where you pick your last talent. Each week a new rotation is done to play a hero for free (but get less XP if you don't own the hero).

Varied maps
Each map brings it's own atmosphere, challenges and recommended traps. No map feels the same in terms of tactics. Some maps even give fun things like one map has swimming sharks. Once an orc dies the shark eat the orcs. Over time you revisit a map only this time the challenge goes up by having bigger, badder and more waves.

Traps
The traps are the main thing about this game. It's fun to place traps and make various combinations. Just like OMD 1 and 2 you can place traps on ceilings, walls and ground. Each trap has it's own use and price. Some traps are better than other. You can upgrade traps to your liking and even customize them a little. Customizing comes in term of catering to your playstyle. For example you use a lot of fire traps? Then gives traps a damage boost when an Orc is on fire!

Unchained
The main addition of the game is that combos gives unchained. Unchained gives the hero HP, mana, cooldown and damage boosts. It's fun to go unchained and see combos fly around.

PvP
The PvP mode is a nice optional addition and gives a fun twist to the moba market. You lead armies and help your armie avoid traps and heroes. You can also build traps to help you defend your rift. I myself hardly play it because I find the PvE mode more fun. But the PvP mode is fun.

Cons
Farm a lot
As many have stated the farming for items just is too much at the moment. You farm items by picking them up, levelling up, getting chest (you get them from time or you buy them), completing quests or completing daily quests. So while you do get enough chance to get items, it's just not enough. The item cost to get traps or upgrade them is just too much at the moment. I need to play like 10-15 games orso to get something. OMD 1 and 2 was accessible in terms of upgrades. Not to mention my bigger gripe with the game is that you yourself have to pick up items in-game. This can't be done because often you'll defend a lane. Items despawn after a round which doesn't make it easier. They do really need to make items pickup group based so everyone gets it. I feel that the farming of the items in this game is the biggest con and needs to fixed for this game to grow.

Queueing is long and weird
at the moment it's just screwed. Sometimes the game matches me with 2 other people for a map that is not balanced for 3 people (but balanced for 5 people). We always lose when this happens. Queuing also takes too long at times.

Enemies destroying barricades
At the moment there are enemies in the game that destroy barricades. Barricades are needed to make a maze so that the Orcs walk a longer path. Some enemies however destroy the barricades within a few seconds. People in end-game have a hard time dealing with this. Heck the most of the game is figuring out an ideal path by placing traps and barricades.

Trap limit too low sometimes
Often people are struggling because the trap limit is too low. Most maps give you 120 traps to the max. This limit is easy to reach in the later levels. I would say 150 trap limit would be better and balances the game more.

reviewText:
Just looking at it and starting it up seems a bit overwhelming, and I can see how negative reviews come into play (thinking it's more based around pay to win), but you CAN play the game without buying anything.

Seeing as it's a free game, there's a lot to it. The only thing you'll ever lose is one or two hours just downloading it. It's extremely fun to play, and playing with friends makes it even better. After getting to use to everything and figuring everything out, it's fairly straight forward. Tutorial is clear and simple, making the game easy to understand.

Edit: This game quickly gets boring without friends, so find four buddies to play with ahead of time or you'll find yourself sitting on the main screen scrolling through reddit or something.

reviewText:
Caution when buying DLC for this game! When I installed the f2p client it gave me the US version (I had no choice). However when buying DLC it was credited to a European Robot Entertainment account. ¨DO NOT PANIC¨. This may happen if you change IP to different continent or your steam settings etc. If this (has) accours with you send an e-mail to Robot Entertainment with above mentioned information. They can confirm purchase on your steam account so make sure your DLC is credited there. If it isnt, go bug steam first! Note; they have informed me they are working with steam on a solution preventing this from happening. So ´coudos´ to RE for their assistance.

Con:
This also means accounts are automaticly dedicated to certain servers. US players wont find their EU friends and vice versa. This can be circumvented by downloading the client directly from RE website however.

At the time of this review it is still in BETA stage. And the netcode clearly has not been optomised. People report long load times and lag/warp hickups. I dont doubt this will be resolved in due time.

Pros:
Now for the game. Well unless you have been living under a rock for the pas 10 years you already know what f2p means. Many publishers ´confuse´ this with p2w. Alas many gamers do too. RE however does not. From what I can tell all stat carrying items can be obtained simply by playing. So its the old story of time vs money. Which will you invest. Of course the regular visual items (no stats) are obtainable with hard currency only. So if you like the game buy some!

OMD-U is the third installment of the series. RE may just be attempting to cash in on their franchise but as far as I am concerned they doing a fair job of it! The 3rd release is a good followup with some new features installed, some old features gone (I still miss my weavers -sad face-) and of course accomedating the new economic system.

If you like tower defence and you dont frown upon FPS games youll enjoy this. I strongly reccomend buying OMD (orcs my die) 1 and 2 if you dont own them already. Do not be put off with them being single or 2 player co-op games. They really help imerse into the franchise!

And as always with all f2p games. its free to try! So hit that install button...

reviewText: I've played this game since Alpha and honestly if you're looking for a decent mix of base defense and moba look elsewhere. Don't waste your time on this trash.

reviewText: A poorly executed mess. It fails as an Orcs Must Die game and it fails as a MOBA. The progression system is insane and it costs £10 to buy a hero with coins. It could've been a better version of a Monday Night Combat game if it was executed better. The servers are also awful for EU, I tried to play this game multiple times over the last couple of days and the servers were down for most of the evening of the first and most of the day for the second.\n\nI tried this game despite the bad reviews and have wasted 2 hours of my life. I urge you to heed my advice and to stay away from this game in it's current state. At least wait until it has been finished.

reviewText:
The game is good, it expands the original concept that was Orcs Must Die! and Orcs Must Die! 2.
I will find it hard for me to grow bored of this game too soon.

I confess I had a few issues in executing the game itself at the start, perhaps they may improve that in the future for lower end platforms to have better access to the servers. Fortunately, the Staff was quite competent and helpful when I requested help, and I managed to get it running without any issues since then.

Regarding what many people say about the Pay 2 Win system.
I don't like it, specially when a player abuses it. The game right now is Free to Play and people can work for the resources (in game) nontheless. ( except for Hero Skins, and maybe other things I haven't seen yet )
We can see this mechanic here as a good thing for those that don't have the time for the grind, and wish to have some help in raising up their game. Here's an example: If I work 8 or 10 hours a day, I won't have the time for grinding, but I do have money from it, so I won't fear falling behind too much.
This is the only scennario which I can accept this. I won't question the developers if they made it for this same reason or not, and frankly, it's none of my business.

Now, I am going to enjoy this game with my friends, hopefully, for a good amount of time.

This is just my say in the matter, everyone is entitled to their opinion.
I like the game and I hope it will earn people's respect

reviewText: Ohh man this game is ♥♥♥♥ING FUN, it is the GREATEST MOBA of all time, those negative reviews are based upon something which is already being fixed (they call it pay to win because they have to earn heroes, it's not pay to win but the devs are changing it anyways).  It is NOT pay to win, it's amazingly fun and I would recommend it to anybody.  The 5v5 pvp siege will be REVOLUTIONARY to the genre.  Great work devs!\n\nI figured I'd specify about the current currency platform.  Basically you earn materials through playing games/getting kills/scoring/etc, and you use that material to craft heroes, traps, minions, and other unlocks, you also of course have the option to buy these unlocks with IRL currency.  People screamed and cried that it takes alot to unlock a hero but that's how it should be.  Nonetheless the devs have said in the recent notes that they are indeed making it easier to obtain heroes.  So I would highly recommend this game.

I played for nearly 5 hours and haven't accumalated near enough materials for crafting anything useful whether traps or even a hero.

I don't have a super computer so when I get to the hero selection screen I only have choice of 1 hero out of the 5 free rotation heroes.  Who wants to play an entire game with a hero they don't like?

The game could be fun if it wasn't so reliant on crafting even starter heroes or items.

Ok so i am in this game for about 4 days i am not for a long time and maybe when others will read i could be about a month... but that does not matter..
So i find this game at jacksepticeye.. i tough it was cool so i tried it on their platform then i go to steam to see (just courious) the reviews.. and i saw only bad review about P2W and things like that..
Ok i know what is pay2win and what is NOT pay2win..
some idiots thing that it have only 1 microtransaction thats it! its P2W but they have no idea what they talk about! lets take a game with microtransaction a MOBA like game , let's take LOL it have micro you put real money and they give you special coints to buy a champion faster in this game is the same thing but the single difference that you have to craft instead of just playing and you get virtual coints...
ppl dont understand what P2W means... so let me explain for you (or maybe you knew what truly means)
so P2W is when a company is maching something lets say OP and you have to pay for it with real money to get it.. and then there are some ppl who DONT want to put money in the game yet or they dont afford it etc.. and then its pay2win cuz you can be VS with a guy with that thing and then is P2W
these idiots from this review thing that this company makes you almost impossible to craft something and they force you to buy it or some ♥♥♥♥ like that.. NO this game is not P2W is in BETA the producers needs money every publisher needs money you will never find a game with 0% microtransaction!!!!


now a pro cons thingy
pro:
its free
nice comunity
no spams on the global chat (at least i did not saw anything)
fun to play and with friends it dubles the fun
NO P2W dont listen to these idiots (and pls after you play put a recommend i like this game and i want to stay here for a while just to attract more ppl and i support indie producers they have all my respect)
easy to master
cons:
somethimes is laggy because is beta
it have some bugs because its beta ( but these bugs are not game braking like go inside a wall or things like this)
instant lockers (because this game dont have enough heroes and they put only 5 heroes free but i understand them)

in conclusion
so play this game i recommend it with all my hearth and i HATE ppl saying ♥♥♥♥ stuff about a game that are NOT true :)

reviewText:
Okay so having playing this game for a while I think I have a decent review for players contemplating on playing this game.
If you haven't played any OMD  like me  you will find it hard to get your head around what the aim of the game actually is but, you will eventually get your head around it, I promise.
People say that it's a 'pay to win' game, in my honest opinion, it isn't. Obviously you can buy stuff from the in-game store however, you can get the same things by playing the game anyway, which leades me on to my next point.
This game requires alot of grinding to be able to achieve new in-game items; traps, heros etc...
This game is alot of fun once you know the aim and what exactly you need to be doing, if you enjoy the game, you wouldn't mind the grind. If you're eagar to buy the best items in-game, you may do so.

I hope this review answers some questions on people wanting to play.

reviewText:
For the fan of Orcs Must Die 1 and 2, this game may not be entirely what you expected it to be.

It has the traditional Survival mode, where you survive waves of orcs, but the progression of survival maps is slower than previously, as they're gated behind account level. This means, that if you're a fan of OMD and is playing this game solely for the survival mode, you're stuck with the low level starter maps for quite a while.

But it isn't all just survival mode, for there is a quite nice and different moba style game as well. You maybe think oh no
hoursPlayed: though needs more characters and refinement. So don't just play the survival mode
voteText: though that is what you may have come for

reviewText: Omdu is a 3rd person hero tower defense game, if that makes sense.  Pick your favorite and coolest looking hero to defend your base from swarms of varying minions 8n the PVE survival mode.  This isn't something you do alone you can have up to 5 partners helping you set up mazes and trap filled rooms to turn any enemy minion into mince meat.  And if Co op defense isn't your thing then you'll enjoy my favorite part of omdu the PVP mode seige in which you Lead varying types of minions inthrough trapped rooms,  heavy guardians and enemy players to the enemy base getting quite a few oh so satisfying kills on the way!\n

reviewText:
Review updated after patches - I really do want to love this game. It has a lot of the things which I like about OMD. There are still some issues, like the matchmaking putting smaller groups up against maps with far more lanes than they can defend or having to play the same map over and over because it won't let you pick what map you would like to play on using the matchmaking mode.

The game needs work balancing reward progression too. At this point it feels extremely slow to advance, I've got to the stage at which I can almost upgrade to level 3 traps but I've only barely been able to upgrade two traps to level 2. Nor have I unlocked all the traps yet.

It still seems like no-one has any idea how the game actually works (no-one understands how to set up traps for combos and they keep running off to fight things instead of letting them get into the killboxes). The only solution seems to be to keep playing until you out level people.

If you really liked Orcs Must Die and you don't mind a lot of grinding (or spending real money) and a little less skill then you'll probably love this game. But it still has a lot of issues (which I hope will get fixed as the game is in 'early access') that make it hard to unreservedly recommend.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very fun and tactical.
Multiple jobs to seperate just mindless deathmatch. Fun characters with a good balance in different roles.
Rewarding when you beat back the other team, or kill another character in the midst of the battle.
Good sound and ques when running around so its easy to stay up on what stage you're in at the battle.

Only thing I think needs to be added is a penalty for disconnecting or leaving a game; especially in siege.
The balance of even one person leaving can set a game to be a loss. Even more so if it is your attacker or defense.
very few games i've won after someone leaves if a pillager picks up the slack because they are getting the bonuses a designated atk or def would get.
I imagine the inability to que for another match for 15mi lol learn to adaptns would be a good incentive for cry babies who don't get the hero or job the wanted, or are just sore losers. LOL learn to adapt and play all the roles as the come and you'll have plenty of fun, even if you don't have the best team sometimes.

reviewText:
Game itself is great and since this is beta it will propably get even better over time. Heroes are cool but I think they are way too expensive to craft, and even if you buy them with real money they are still too expensive and skins are ridiculously over prised. I also dont like that you cant choose yor favourite hero in PvE games if you are little bit too slow, I get that they want everyone on team to play as a different hero but I dont think that is nessessary, it would be more fun to use my own hero every game especcially if I but real money on that hero or have grinded 20+ hours just to get my favourite hero, heroes are really that hard to get without real money. For exsample if I want to buy enough gold to buy smoulder and a skin, it would cost over 20 euros, over 20 to get one hero wich you cant even play if someone else choose that hero faster than you, this is a single biggest problem in this game.

Edit 1: New big proplem that has happened now many times, when match is about to start game crashes and reboots my computer.

Edit 2: They lowered hero crafting prices and i think they are now balanced, less than 10 hours to get one hero, that is well balanced in my opinion.

reviewText:
Very fun and tactical.
Multiple jobs to seperate just mindless deathmatch. Fun characters with a good balance in different roles.
Rewarding when you beat back the other team, or kill another character in the midst of the battle.
Good sound and ques when running around so its easy to stay up on what stage you're in at the battle.

Only thing I think needs to be added is a penalty for disconnecting or leaving a game; especially in siege.
The balance of even one person leaving can set a game to be a loss. Even more so if it is your attacker or defense.
very few games i've won after someone leaves if a pillager picks up the slack because they are getting the bonuses a designated atk or def would get.
I imagine the inability to que for another match for 15mi lol learn to adaptns would be a good incentive for cry babies who don't get the hero or job the wanted, or are just sore losers. LOL learn to adapt and play all the roles as the come and you'll have plenty of fun, even if you don't have the best team sometimes.

reviewText: Hi guys this is my first review ever , but seeing that there is a lot of mixed reviews about this game i would just like to tell you guys how amazing it is, because i would really like to see more people comming into the game and increasing its playerbase wich right now is very low unfortunally, wich unfortunally will cause you sometimes to have unbalanced games, but hey where in the world did i ever play a MOBA 9wich ive been playing for around 6 years now) where i didnt get unbalanced games? Ive seen a lot of comments about the problem of grinding in this game, but guys open your eyes League of Legends is one of the most played MOBAS around and the game IS PURELLY GRINDING!!!!! just because you dont have items to farm but money instead it doesnt make it any better, not forgetting that the grinding on some games will actually give you a boost against enemie teams, well the DEV os this game had a really nice idea, why you ask? because all the items that would make the game unbalanced are only available on SURVIVAL mode wich is a co-op mode, making the SIEGE mode fair to everyone. Ive been playing for around 3 weeks now and i managed to get already a lot of traps , champs and so on... the DEV even came with a reward system that every other game they will give you a box wich can contain mostly anyhting!!!! Ive earned new minions, new traps , new comsumable FOR FREE... what grinding did i need to do on those? none cuz the game rewards you with it!!!! sorry but never in playing mobas have i seen something like this ( dota will rewars you with ocasional skin parts but thats it) so dont make the grinding stop you from playing this game because its not what it looks yes the survival might be more fun when you get everything unlocked but u can always go back to playing OMD1 and OMD2 but if u wanna have fun with a group of friends give it a change, ive managed to do maps wich shoudl be made with 5 people with just a friend and that was a thrill , but if its not for you try siege you'll love it and besides so far the comunity is far better then any mobva i've played!!!!!

reviewText: I had HUGE hopes for this game, being a diehard fan of the first and second Orcs Must Die! games. I even invested $20 into the game when it was in alpha. Sadly, the developers really missed the mark with this game. I loved the first game because of the traps, the combat, and the adrenaline rush. This game's traps are basically worthless, and the focus is more on hero abilities. It's basically just a third-person shooter MOBA. There's no more of the charm that the other OMD games had.\nIt seems like this game loses a part of its soul every time it gets a sequel. The first one was perfect, the second one wasn't quite as fun but co-op added some fun to it, and now that it's pure multiplayer with little focus on traps and the whole puzzle strategy" of the originals
date: it's just without any charm at all.\nAlso

reviewText:
I've put 8 hours into this game and I want to put more into it. I like playing it alone and as I've not played the other Orcs Must Die I thought I would give this a try due to it being free. I've yet to play Multiplayer, even in survival mode, and I don't know if I ever will, but I know that I'm enjoying what I've seen thus-far.

However, I still would not reccomend this game. The price-gating is silly, worse even than Heroes of the Storm. Whereas Heroes of the Storm gives you one resource to grind (Gold) and that can unlock all of the non-cosmetic content in the game, OMD:U gives you about 20 different resources to be used in crafting everything from traps to minions to heroes. It is cumbersome just trying to figure out what resources are needed for what content and the amount being asked for a lot of these crafted good, ESPECIALLY the heroes, is way above what I would consider to be reasonable.

8 hours in I've had no issues with traps. I've made do and honestly with the hero I've been maining I don't think I need many more at this point, but I don't own this hero and if she moves out of the rotation then I'm stuck and my setup that has been doing me very well suddenly becomes a lot less viable.

I am willing to grind to unlock stuff. I've not spent a penny on Heroes of the Storm, but the cost of the heroes is staggering, the cost of everything else I can see some justification for, but the variety of crafting materials is unhelpful, the crafting system is hard to get a handle on, and I feel if I were a less patient guy this game would just be too much for me to stand.

So I can't in all good faith recommend this game. If the team drastically revamp how the crafting works, and the pricing on the heroes, then I may even put some money into it, but as it stands I can't and won't pay for a game that so transparently wants to inconvenience me into paying.

reviewText: I know at the time of this writing I only have a few hours in this game, but all of the negativity aimed at it solely for it's microtransactions are obscuring some of the other things that should be talked about here. Yes, this game will obviously be a grind without paying actual money for materials, but everything that effects stats or traps can be earned. The rest is cosmetic. This is pretty common with this sort of game and uncommon for it to be any other way in a free to play multiplayer title. I hate to make the argument well it's free" but
date: hey it's free. So as not to rant
recommended:
I'll do the normal bullet point pros and cons.

PROS
- The game you love
hoursPlayed: Orcs Must Die
voteText:
is here and still fun.
- It is much easier than the last 2 iterations in the series to set up a co-op game.
- You do not have to play the MOBA portion of the game
- Working together is important and there is a lot of meta-strategy
helpfulPercent:
but it's easy to get the hang of.
- It looks better graphically than the last 2 and performs better on lower end systems.
- The gamepad support is top notch.

CONS
- Sometimes games will boot you at the loading screen. You can hop right back into your game though
votesHelpful:
much like League of Legends.
- The client is super glitchy. Sometimes your cursor does nothing and then other times buttons will refuse to load.
- There really isn't a way to mess around with graphics setting. All you can do is change the ratio. This NEEDs to be fixed.
- The pricing on the microtransactions are hardly "micro".
- The drops rates for some of the crafting items are nearly non-existent.


I think this game is getting an unfair rep and I'll revisit this review somewhere down the road."

reviewText:
Where do I start on this horrible appendium to the Orcs Must Die series? Well, first off, I'll leave out elements that are, I assume, are Beta issues, like lag, frequent pausing/freezing, etc. That should shorten up my review by quiet a bit.

Here goes (In order of launching the game (ish)):
1. What the absolute H*ll robot? You make me create a F**K*N account? Why the H*ll can't I use my steam account to play the G*dd*mn game through Steam like every other game that you have created? Get real or GTFO! I'm a die hard Orcs Must Die guy, and have been championing a multiplayer game now for years, but I will not settle for this Sh*t! You can pull my Steam info and create all the info you need to create the game. I am not going to add yet another site, username, password combo to my long list of accounts just so you guys can get your kicks and giggles looking at the number of people signing up for a useless, pointless, non-transferable account.
2. What the absolute H**l robot? You make me create a F**K*N account and then require me to add my friends that I already have in Steam AGAIN through your F**k*d up account crap? Seriously? What the absolute H*ll!?!?!?!?! NO!!!!!!!! Just NO! Go peddle your crapware elsewhere, like the bottom of the sea. Maybe then I can hid from this garbage.  Seriously! I have a list of friends that I already play with on Steam. We all like each other, we all know each other, and we all play with each other. Now I have to call them, find out what username they used to sign up with you F**ked up excuse for a Steam bypass, and then do a friend request swap WHICH WE HAVE ALREADY F**K*N DONE YOU IDIOTS! Just so we can play the game.
3. You ruined Orcs Must Die franchise. The game was about problem solving co-op play. Now with this game, it's about FPS grinding. Seriously, sh*t gameplay. All you had to do was create bigger maps, add in more characters, and boom, you would have had a winner. But nooooooooooo, you A**Ho*es had to go and limit the number of traps and turn it into a grinder game. Good job in ruining a lifelong fan. Sanctum 2 anyone? Yup these guys ripped it off play, by play only with orcs.

In short, I'm giving it a chance because it is in Beta after all, but I seriously will not spend a single penny on this game if this is the crap they release. B**lSh*t!

I'll update as Robot makes updates...

reviewText: The core mechanics have some promise, but because of the F2P model and the relentless focus on multiplayer, it just does not provide the fun solo experience that its predessors have.  Long ago, I reviewed OMD1 as the best of its contemporaries (the gorgeous Sanctum and addictive Dungeon Defenders) on the basis of having the best and most focused solo experience.  OMD2 lost some of that luster, with its two-player co-op focus.  OMD:U abandons it entirely.  I'm very sad about that.\n\nIf you're looking for a game to play with friends, it might have more potential.  But I am clearly no longer the target audience for Robot.  I'm not bitter at all.  Honest.  ;p

reviewText:
Looking through previous reviews I can see that many people dislike this game because progress can be quite slow. While this is very true and without paying it can take a RIDICULOUS amount of time I would like to point out that it is a free-to-play game and there does have to be some way to incline people to spend money ingame.

However the gameplay is fantastic, especially the siege maps. The feeling of upgrading, attacking and defending all as a team with your own traps AND minions is a truly exhilirating feeling and makes for and excellent RPG/strategy/whatever game.

I would also like to point out that, again progress is slow, but you do not need to progress to be good at the game and have fun. I have played a few hours and my favourite hero has to be midnight, one of the starting heroes. I find myself doing just fine using her against heroes that people have bought in the battlefield.

If you strike out on your own and fight a bunch of  enemies, yes, you are probably going to die, but thats how its supposed to be. The game is about teamwork and strategy and even if you're a tank character you're still not likely to succeed on your own.

Overall the gameplay is very fun and I feel though it is still true to classic OMD gameplay it is well binded to the multiplayer mechanics and is truly worth your time if your considering playing. It is definitely worth money so you might as well try it cause its free.

P.S. Hogarth is ♥♥♥♥, no offense.

reviewText:
Orcs must Die Unchained, exactly what OMD 1 & 2 are and much more.
Negative reviews? Most of them because of the Publisher being Gameforge, blah blah another moba and game's Pay2Win.
Gameforge is fine.
Moba? Nah.
Pay2Win? If you for some reason want to be in higher levels of Survival gamemode faster, Pay to progress faster.
Which I wouldn't do if someone wishes to keep up with the increasing demand of skills.
You cannot use Potions/Consumables on the 5v5 PvP Siege as people understand. ( Being the hugest foundation of the Pay2Win statement )
They can be used in the PvE Survival, to keep you alive for that couple more seconds to get that rift safe.
-- It's a truly new game we haven't ever seen. --
Do you like Tower defence? 3'rd person shooters? Hunt people down? Try 'dis, and thank Robot for the third OMD game out here.

Please ignore the fact I have 0 Hours, I've been there since Alpha, and I regret nothing.
10/10 For the contiuous orc murdering.

Edit: Removed typoed lines.

reviewText:
As a player of OMD and OMD2 I had high hopes for this and on balance I haven't been dissappointed. I agree with many others that progression is slow but I actually don't mind that too much myself. I've only logged around 130 hours at time of writing, but thats more than I've had out of games I bought so I really can't complain!

The game itself I really enjoy - placing traps and watching them decimate minions is great fun. Where I have a real problem is the often (I say often because its not everyone) over critical community with little or no tolerance for new players entering PVP games. Instead of offering advice, games are instead sprinkled with name calling and abuse from other players. And even when advice is offered from players to other people, its often ignored (possibly due to language barriers).

As for the game itself, you can either play in pvp or pve modes. Heros are rotated weekly at the moment with 5 heros available per week free to play. Others can be crafted with stuff dropped in games, or bought from the shop. At 134 hours I've crafted 2 heros with enough saved for a third. To give an idea of the time it takes to progress, I've made around 4-5 traps, 2 bosses, 2 trinkets, 2 traits and several minion types as well as upgrading two traps to level 2 for PVE (upgraded traps dont have anu extra effect in PVP).

In PvP mode, you choose a character, select a role (Pillager, Defender or Attacker) and select your deck (basically your loadout of traps, traits, items, minions and bosses that will be available to you in the game).

Defenders (usually 2): Defend the rift (the zone that enemy minions try to reach) by laying traps and shooting/hitting enemy minions that try to get past you. Maximising combo's and use of barricades to channel minions to kill boxes is important to these players. As a free tip: Do not line the walls/floor with arrows and spikes!

Attackers (usually 2): Escort friendly minions to the enemies rift and decide which minions to deploy in each friendly portal. They gain XP points for being near friendly minions and place glyphs (which also buffs minions) if they are available to the character. Attackers shouldnt normally be placing traps as a matter of course.

Pillager (usually 1): This character roams the battlefield shooting caches/crates (coloured red) and gathering XP from them. They can also help either attacker or defender when needed by ganking another player by surprise or simply killing enemy minions if your defenders need help. They would not normally place traps.

On each map there is also a Boss that can be summoned by one team or the other if they complete the objective for that map. On one map its to kill a beast and cook the steak that is dropped in the middle of the map. On the other its to capture two flags on either side of the map by standing in the zone. Once complete, you place a boss in the minion portal shortly after help him lumber towards the enemy rift.

PVP games last anywhere between 10-35 minutes depending on the skill level of people involved.

In PvE mode, you go alone, with a group of friends or use the matchmaking system to group with some random players. The game is then very similar to the original Orcs Must Die! games with players basically building traps to stop the minions reaching your rift. You all are effectively playing as defending, coordinating kill box design and earning coin to place yet more traps. It's fun, although my preference is more towards PvP at the moment.

As for Pay to Win, I would say this is certainly not:

1. People can buy hero's sure (but there are 5 on rotation and you can craft them
yourself if you want).
2. People can buy chests which grant materials/cards for crafting new stuff like traps. You can make these yourself with enough time and because its fun to play, it doesn't feel grindy. Just level up on some PvE missions, gather the materials and make more stuff.
3. The only thing you can't gather without paying is the customisable skins for characters which are purly aesthetic (as far as I know).

reviewText:
I didn't spend very long with this game before reviewing it and I didn't feel like I needed to. There were three big reasons for me giving a negative review, things that immediately stuck out and made me want to exit the game and uninstall.

First and foremost is the awful free to play model they've gone for. Something I really liked from the first two games was beating more and more difficult challenges to unlock everything. It felt rewarding! They've decided to replace that with a combination of extreme grinding and high prices. Take a look at the forums and you can see people already complaining about the grind.  What's even worse is that even if you do decide to dump $50 into this game that package doesn't seem to be enough to even unlock all of the characters, forget the rest of the stuff in the game that you may want. If you aren't sick to your stomach yet: The game is p2w as well. It seems like all the 'consumables' in the shop (which you buy with real money after suffering through 'exchanging' it for arbitrarily useless amounts of in-game currency) give distinct in-game advantages. Are you interested in spending real money to get a healing potion? This is your game.

Second, this game just doesn't 'feel' like an OMD game. It sort of plays like a shoddy knockoff. The graphics are either the same or worse than OMD2. In the couple levels I played your characters abilities just don't seem very impactful or interesting compared to earlier games.

Third, and I realize this tends to invite a lot of controversy/babyrage, but for the most part I found the character design to be cliched and lame. Nearly every female hero is a ranged/stealth/magic archetype. They mostly have the same predictable 'pornstar' body type with equally predictable battle-bikini costumes. Throw in some infantilizing style choices for the non 'sexy' character and you've got a well rounded roster of gross cliches.  I didn't look at every skin for every character but it seems pretty obvious from the loading screen/promotional art what they're going for. The male characters have a huge range of ages, body types, and even species! One of the male characters actually is somewhat scantily clad, but given his bizarre proportions it seems to be a comedic choice rather than sex appeal. Maybe you don't care about this and think it's fine. Good for you, I don't want to hear it. It was enough to contribute to deterring me from the game so I included it.

Yes the game is in Beta, but they seemed to think it was finished enough to show to the public. Unless their development plans involve completely replacing the f2p model and redoing all the art, I don't think these problems will get any better with time.

reviewText:
Autistic Orcs must Die is a better name. Very buggy. I was able to run through walls. Got stuck inside walls. The tutorial was bugged out for me. Could have been an issue with the install. But the tutorial wouldn't show the display buttons at all. And from what I seen of this game, it is a repetitious, monotonous, and lacks any sense of content or strategy whatso ever.

Claims to have partial controller support, it don't. Xpadder works fine though. The game is free, so I don't really have much of a right to  b1tch about it. Just not something I would recommend to others unless they were a child. Too kiddish. The graphics look like they were meant to appeal to kids.

I will wait for the game to be out of beta before I try again. I believe my issue was a faulty install. But from what I seen of the game, don't like it at all. A biased opinion. You might like the game. It is free, give it a try. If you don't like it, just uninstall it like I did.

Don't take my review as personal, as I stated. It is a BIASED opinion. Just try it out for yourself. It is free.

reviewText:
I didn't spend very long with this game before reviewing it and I didn't feel like I needed to. There were three big reasons for me giving a negative review, things that immediately stuck out and made me want to exit the game and uninstall.

First and foremost is the awful free to play model they've gone for. Something I really liked from the first two games was beating more and more difficult challenges to unlock everything. It felt rewarding! They've decided to replace that with a combination of extreme grinding and high prices. Take a look at the forums and you can see people already complaining about the grind.  What's even worse is that even if you do decide to dump $50 into this game that package doesn't seem to be enough to even unlock all of the characters, forget the rest of the stuff in the game that you may want. If you aren't sick to your stomach yet: The game is p2w as well. It seems like all the 'consumables' in the shop (which you buy with real money after suffering through 'exchanging' it for arbitrarily useless amounts of in-game currency) give distinct in-game advantages. Are you interested in spending real money to get a healing potion? This is your game.

Second, this game just doesn't 'feel' like an OMD game. It sort of plays like a shoddy knockoff. The graphics are either the same or worse than OMD2. In the couple levels I played your characters abilities just don't seem very impactful or interesting compared to earlier games.

Third, and I realize this tends to invite a lot of controversy/babyrage, but for the most part I found the character design to be cliched and lame. Nearly every female hero is a ranged/stealth/magic archetype. They mostly have the same predictable 'pornstar' body type with equally predictable battle-bikini costumes. Throw in some infantilizing style choices for the non 'sexy' character and you've got a well rounded roster of gross cliches.  I didn't look at every skin for every character but it seems pretty obvious from the loading screen/promotional art what they're going for. The male characters have a huge range of ages, body types, and even species! One of the male characters actually is somewhat scantily clad, but given his bizarre proportions it seems to be a comedic choice rather than sex appeal. Maybe you don't care about this and think it's fine. Good for you, I don't want to hear it. It was enough to contribute to deterring me from the game so I included it.

Yes the game is in Beta, but they seemed to think it was finished enough to show to the public. Unless their development plans involve completely replacing the f2p model and redoing all the art, I don't think these problems will get any better with time.

reviewText:
This is not a Tower-Defense, this is a just a bad, one-button third-person-shooter. No mazes, no puzzles. Traps do less than 25% of the killing work. Instead of mazing and creating a good killing box you have to build three or more boxes separately and kill most of the Orcs holding down you left mouse-button. Progression is extremely slow including endless grinds and replaying the same over and over again.

Though PvP gameply is definitely very well made, it lost the feeling of a TD (which made OMD2 good) completely.

Despite being in beta, overall I'm disappointed. They really need to rethink balancing and redo the maps, to make it a good game in the end.

reviewText:
Many people complain about the crafting system, and I will agree it's a pain point for this game. To get to a new trap or hero or piece of gear you really need to get a huge amount of games done. But the thing that really gets people is that the crafting mats are completely random, so it could take you anywhere from 30-100 games to get to a certain item.

This is largely frustrating because I feel like of you ignore that glaring problem the game is relatively fun, free-to-play and an okay succesor to the OMD franchise. I've had a good few laughs at the character dialogue, some great moments with trap combos and some very satifying wins with their PvP. It's almost enough to make up for the fact that past your first dozen or so hours of play you won't get anything worthwhile to add to your arsenal for a painfully long time.

But this isn't what made me stop playing. What made me stop playing was the game's level difference filter. To explain, if you group up with a friend (in PvE) who is 10-15 levels higher or lower than you you cannot que in the matchmaker and it'll just be the two of you. The level scales with number of players so it's not like the level is impossible. But what this does is that it prevents me (the higher one of my friend group) from doing anything without then making it harder for my friends to catch up. I was literally punished for playing the game if I wanted to play with friends.

Combine this with the painful crafting system, several underpowered traps, slow hero balance and small hero roster my faith in Robot's capability to refine this game into a worthwhile experience (for the amount of time they're trying to squeeze out of you) has been eroded greatly.

reviewText:
From the makers of Orcs must die! comes the next step, move OMD2 nice coop gameplay to 5 man. Or perharps 10 if you like pvp? The game plays like classic OMD, target, shoot or swing, place traps, etc. Aim properly, dont get hit too much, play smart, and dont lose a single second!

The game is still in beta, open beta now. I started playin it in closed beta, while the previous system was active, you could buy everything with skulls (and or gold with the exeption of skin).

Now the game has changed in how it implement its F2P, using an elaborated crafting system with multiple requirement, Skulls being the base. Some improvements over the old system seems to be in encouraging diversification of play and encouraging long term engagement, as well as some possible upgrade over nromal traps (waiting to test that). I have no strong opinion for or against it yet, i need to play it some more. Given that the game is free and all you need is time investment and to have fun while playing, it might be hard to claim (for me) that it is a big negative, maybe just a bit slow, but not the slowest ive seen. Plus you can always pay to get hero faster, skins, and a few random goodies. The system is still mosly the same: you need to play, and over time youll get enough for new..everything. You cannot pay to quickly earn anything specific (beside hero/skins) you want, but you could earn something random, by buying chests or from one earned during a game!

The gameplay always has been solid as far i played, direct, effetive. You can recognise the OMD franchise, especially if you like to play defence a bit.

I haven't encountered any of the major issues some have mentioned, not before not now. For me the good far outweight the bad right now.

The game can carve a small niche in the MOBA market for being more than simple minions waves in lane, the traps and hero part is what make it work. Every investment, movement, action, can comeback and turn out to be a good choices, or bad. Did you leave to assist offence? surprise defense is being overwhelmed by an extra attacker themselves! Going back to try and help, could risk your entire offence! Maybe one of them is missing, lurking near your base hunting for someone? maybe they are rushing to get the second lane open to put more pressure and split the defender's ressources?

All in all, it's a solid game in it's own right, and i hope it will keep improving. As everything grow, so will this game future.

-Lost

Edit: and i just found out you can play solo survival OMD which also lets you earn components without stress, this is great!

re-Edit: with the latest patch, the crafting just got simplified and survival feels even more like the OMD-OMD2 of old. The game keeps improving and thats what we want to see in a goos game! The game is still not P2W, and that's great!
